revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=July 2018}} The '''Five Safes''' is a framework for helping make decisions about making effective use of data which is confidential or sensitive. It is mainly used to describe or design research access to statistical data held by government agencies, and by data archives such as the UK Data Service.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/use-data/secure-lab/security-philosophy|title=UK Data Service|website=www.ukdataservice.ac.uk|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref>
Two of the Five Safes refer to [[statistical disclosure control]] (SDC), and so the Five Safes is usually used to contrast statistical and non-statistical controls when comparing data management options.
== Concept == The Five Safes proposes that data management decisions be considered as solving problems in five 'dimensions': projects, people, settings, data and outputs. These are most commonly expressed as questions, for example:<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Desai|first=Tanvi|last2=Ritchie|first2=Felix|last3=Welpton|first3=Richard|year=2016|title=Five Safes: designing data access for research|url=http://www2.uwe.ac.uk/faculties/BBS/Documents/1601.pdf|journal=Bristol Business School Working Papers in Economics|volume=|pages=Footnote 1|via=}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/be4aa82cd8cf7f07ca2570d60018da27/e4d483bab4e1ad93ca257f4c00170bb6!OpenDocument|title=1015.0 - Information Paper: Transforming Statistics for the Future|last=|first=|date=2016|website=www.abs.gov.au|publisher=Australian Bureau of Statistics|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" |Safe projects |Is this use of the data appropriate? |- |Safe people |Can the users be trusted to use it in an appropriate manner? |- |Safe settings |Does the access facility limit unauthorised use? |- |Safe data |Is there a disclosure risk in the data itself? |- |Safe outputs |Are the statistical results non-disclosive? |} These dimensions are scales, not limits. That is, solutions can have a mix of more or fewer controls in each dimension, but the overall solution is 'safe' independent of the particular mix. For example, a public use file available for open download cannot control who uses it, where or for what purpose, and so all the control (protection) must be in the data itself. In contrast, a file which is only accessed through a secure environment with certified users can contain very sensitive information: the non-statistical controls allow the data to be 'unsafe'. One academic likened the process to a graphic equalizer,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McEachern|first=Steve|year=2015|title=Implementation of the Trusted Access Model|url=http://rsss.anu.edu.au/sites/default/files/SMcEachern_researcherperspective_ASSANov2015.pdf|journal=Australian Data Archive|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> where bass and treble can be combined independently to produce a sound the listener likes.
The Five Safes concept is associated with other topics which developed from the same programme at ONS, although these are not necessarily implemented. Safe people is associated with 'active researcher management',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unece.org/stats/documents/ece/ces/ge.46/2009/wp.15.e.pdf|title=Effective Researcher Management|last=Desai|first=Tanvi|last2=Ritchie|first2=Felix|date=2009|website=www.unece.org|publisher=Eurostat|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> while safe outputs is linked with [[principles-based output statistical disclosure control]]. The Five Safes is associated with the 'Data Access Spectrum': as the non-data controls tend to work together, these are contrasted with data detail reduction to present a linear representation of data access options.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://gcoe.ier.hit-u.ac.jp/CAED/papers/id213_Ritchie.pdf |title=Designing a national model for data access|last=Ritchie|first=Felix|date=2008|work=Comparative Analysis of Enterprise (Micro)Data 2008 |access-date=11 July 2018}}</ref>
== History and terminology == The Five Safes was devised in the winter of 2002/2003 by Felix Ritchie at the UK [[Office for National Statistics]] (ONS) to describe its secure remote-access Virtual Microdata Laboratory (VML).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ritchie|first=Felix|year=2008|title=Secure access to confidential microdata: four years of the Virtual Microdata Laboratory|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/rel/elmr/economic-and-labour-market-review/no--5--may-2008/secure-access-to-confidential-microdata--four-years-of-the-virtual-microdata-laboratory.pdf|journal=Economic and Labour Market Statistics|volume=2:5|pages=29–34|via=}}</ref> It was described at this time as the 'VML Security Model'. This was adopted by the [[NORC at the University of Chicago|NORC]] data enclave,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Lane|first=Julia|authorlink=Julia Lane|last2=Bowie|first2=Chet|last3=Scheuren|first3=Fritz|last4=Mulcahy|first4=Tim|year=2009|title=NORC Data Enclave:Providing Secure Remote Access to Sensitive Microdata|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/documents/1001617/4398365/S02P1-NORC-DATA-ENCLAVE-SCHEUREN.ppt|journal=UNECE/EU Workshop on statistical confidentiality 2009|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> and more widely in the US, as the 'portfolio model' (although this is now also used to refer to a slightly different legal/statistical/educational breakdown).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lane|first=Julia|last2=Heus|first2=Pascal|last3=Mulcahy|first3=Tim|year=2008|title=Data Access in a Cyber World: Making Use of Cyberinfrastructure|url=https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/ce88/76858c14560afd6d8bd3e8bcae8425d33cab.pdf|journal=Transactions in Data Privacy|volume=|pages=2–16|via=}}</ref> In 2012 the framework as was still being referred to as the 'VML security model',<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Felix|first=Ritchie,|date=2013-01-01|title=International access to restricted data: A principles-based standards approach|url=http://www.medra.org/servlet/aliasResolver?alias=iospress&genre=article&issn=1874-7655&volume=29&issue=4&spage=289&doi=10.3233/SJI-130780|journal=Statistical Journal of the IAOS|language=en|volume=29|issue=4|doi=10.3233/sji-130780|issn=1874-7655}}</ref> but its increasing use among non-UK organisations led to the adoption of the more general and informative phrase 'Five Safes'.<ref name=":0" />
The original framework only had four safes (projects, people, settings and outputs): the framework was used to describe highly detailed data access through a secure environment, and so the 'data' dimension was irrelevant. From 2007 onwards, 'safe data' was included as the framework was used to a describe a wider range of ONS activities. As the US version was based upon the 2005 specification, some US iterations uses have the original four dimensions (eg<ref name=":1" />).
Some discussions, such as the OECD,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/std/microdata-access-final-report-OECD-2014.pdf|title=OECD Expert Group For International Collaboration On Microdata Access, Chapter 6. Standardised Application Process For Microdata Access|last=Volkow|first=Natalia|date=|website=www.oecd.org|publisher=OECD|pages=73–79|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> use the term 'secure' instead 'safe'.
== Application == The framework has had three uses: pedagogical, descriptive, and design. The latter is a relatively recent development.
=== Pedagogy === The first significant use of the framework, other than internal administrative use, was to structure researcher training courses at the UK Office for National Statistics from 2003. [[UK Data Archive]], [[Administrative Data Research Network]], [[Eurostat]], [[Statistics New Zealand]], the Mexican [[National Institute of Statistics and Geography (Mexico)|National Institute of Statistics and Geography]], [[NORC at the University of Chicago|NORC]] and the [[Australian Bureau of Statistics]], amongst others, have also used this framework. Most of these courses are for researchers using restricted-access facilities; the Eurostat courses<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/microdata/overview/self-study-material-for-microdata-users|title=Self-study material for the users of European microdatasets|last=|first=|date=|website=ec.europa.eu|publisher=European Commission|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> are unusual in that they are designed for all users of sensitive data.
=== Description === The framework is often used to describe existing data access solutions (e.g. UK [[HM Revenue and Customs|HMRC]] Data Lab,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.slideserve.com/stephen-hester/the-hmrc-datalab|title=The HMRC Datalab|last=Hawkins|first=Mike|date=2011|website=slideserve.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> UK Data Service,<ref name=":3" /> Statistics New Zealand<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/stats/documents/ece/ces/ge.46/2013/Topic_3_NZ.pdf|title=Confidentiality for integrated data|last=Camden|first=Mike|date=2011|website=www.unece.org|publisher=Eurostat|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref>) or planned/conceptualised ones (e.g. Eurostat in 2011<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/stats/documents/ece/ces/ge.46/2011/43_Eurostat.pdf|title=The Future of Access to European Confidential Data for Scientific Purposes|last=Bujnowska|first=Aleksandra|last2=Museux|first2=Jean-Marc|date=2011|website=www.unece.org|publisher=Eurostat|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref>). An early use<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ritchie|first=Felix|year=2005|title=Access to business microdata in the UK: dealing with the irreducible risks|url=http://www.unece.org/fileadmin/DAM/stats/documents/ece/ces/ge.46/2005/wp.29.e.pdf|journal=UNECE/Eurostat Workshop on Statistical Data Confidentiality 2005|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> was to help identify areas where ONS' still had 'irrreducible risks' in its provision of secure remote access.
The framework is mostly used for confidential social science data. To date it appears to have made little impact on medical research planning,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Green|first=Elizabeth|year=2015|others=et al|title=Enabling data linkage to maximise the value of public health research data|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/stellent/groups/corporatesite/@policy_communications/documents/web_document/wtp059017.pdf|journal=Public Health Research Data Forum Commissioned Reports|publisher=Wellcome Trust|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> although it is now included in the revised guidelines on implementing [[HIPAA]] regulations<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.nap.edu/catalog.php?record_id=18614|title=Proposed Revisions to the Common Rule for the Protection of Human Subjects in the Behavioral and Social Sciences|last=Council|first=National Research|date=2014-01-09|isbn=9780309298063|language=en|doi=10.17226/18614}}</ref> in the US, and by Cancer Research UK and the [[Health Foundation]] in the UK.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://ukdataservice.ac.uk/media/604145/19_5safes_safesettings_wolters.pdf|title=Governance and the HSCIC's IG toolkit|last=Wolters|first=Arne|date=2015|website=ukdataservice.ac.uk|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> It has also been used to describe a security model for the Scottish Health Informatics Programme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.rss.org.uk/uploadedfiles/userfiles/files/Frank-Sullivan-linkage.ppt|title=The Scottish Health Informatics Programme|last=Sullivan|first=Frank|date=|website=www.rss.org.uk|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref>
=== Design === In general the Five Safes has been used to describe solutions post-factum, and to explain/justify choices made, but an increasing number of organisations have used the framework to design data access solutions. For example, the Hellenic Statistical Agency developed a data strategy built around the Five Safes in 2016; the UK Health Foundation used the Five Safes to design its data management and training programmes.<ref name=":4" />
The major design use is in Australia: both the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Department of Social Service used the Five Safes as an ex ante design tool.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://eprints.uwe.ac.uk/31874/|title=Department of Social Services data access project final report. Project Report |last=Green |first=Elizabeth |date=2016|work=|access-date=|last2=Ritchie|first2=Felix}}</ref> In 2017 the Australian Productivity Commission recommended<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.pc.gov.au/inquiries/completed/data-access/report|title=Data Availability and Use: Australian Productivity Commission Inquiry Report|last=|first=|publisher=Productivity Commission |year=2017|isbn=978-1-74037-617-4|location=|pages=}}</ref> adopting a version of the framework to support cross-government data sharing and re-use.
In 2015 the UK Data Service organized a workshop<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/news-and-events/eventsitem/?id=4058|title=The 5 safes of access to confidential data |last=|first=|date=|website=www.ukdataservice.ac.uk|publisher=UK Data Service|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> to encourage data users from the academic and private sectors to think about how to manage confidential research data, using the Five Safes to demonstrate alternative options and best practice.
Two laws have incorporated the Fives Safes: explicitly in the South Australian [https://www.legislation.sa.gov.au/LZ/C/A/PUBLIC%20SECTOR%20(DATA%20SHARING)%20ACT%202016.aspx Public Sector (Data Sharing) Act 2016], implicitly in the research provisions of the [[Digital Economy Act 2017|Digital Economy Act]].
== Public engagement == The UK Data Service has produced a blog<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.ukdataservice.ac.uk/access-to-sensitive-data-for-research-the-5-safes/|title=Access to sensitive data for research: the five safes|last=Welpton|first=Richard|last2=Corti|first2=Louise|date=|website=blog.ukdataservice.ac.ukpublisher=UK Data Service|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> and video<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/embed/Mln9T52mwj0|title=Five Safes video|last=|first=|date=|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=UK Data Service|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> for the general public about the use of Five Safes in re-using administrative data. Statistics New Zealand produced a non-technical description,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/browse_for_stats/snapshots-of-nz/integrated-data-infrastructure/keep-data-safe.aspx|title=How we keep IDI data safe|last=|first=|date=|website=www.stats.govt.nzpublisher=Statistics New Zealand|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref> as did ONS for [[Data Privacy Day]] 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blog.ons.gov.uk/2017/01/27/the-five-safes-data-privacy-at-ons/|title=The Five Safes: data privacy at ONS|last=Stokes|first=Pete|date=2017|website=blog.ons.gov.uk|publisher=Office for National Statistics|access-date=2017-01-28}}</ref>
==References== '''Notes''' {{notelist}} '''Citations''' {{reflist|30em}}

{{EngvarB|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Infobox Christian leader | type = [[Bishop]] | honorific-prefix = [[Bishop]] | name = G. B. Devasahayam | honorific-suffix = [[Church of South India|CSI]] | title = [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] – in – [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = మహ గనుడు గొనె బెంజమిన్ దేవసహాయం అయ్యాగారు | native_name_lang = te | church = [[Protestant]] [[Church of South India]]
''(comprising [[Wesleyan Church|Wesleyan Methodist]], [[Congregational]] and [[Anglican]] missionary societies - [[United Society|SPG]], [[English Wesleyan Mission|WMMS]], [[London Missionary Society|LMS]], [[Church Missionary Society|CMS]], and the [[Church of England]])'' | archdiocese = | province = | metropolis = | diocese = [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]] | see = [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Wesley Cathedral, [[Karimnagar]] | elected = 1982 | term = 1982 - 1987 | quashed = | predecessor = [[B. Prabhudass]] | successor = [[K. E. Swamidass]] | opposed = | other_post = | ordination = | ordained_by = [[Frank Whittaker]], [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Medak Diocese|Medak]] | consecration = 1982, [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Wesley Cathedral, [[Karimnagar]] | consecrated_by = The Most Reverend [[I. Jesudasan]], Moderator, The Right Reverend Sundar Clarke, Deputy ModeratorK. M. George, ''Church of South India: life in union, 1947–1997'', Jointly published by Indian Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge and Christava Sahitya Samithi, Tiruvalla, 1999, p.108. [https://books.google.com/books?um=1&q=] | cardinal = | created_cardinal_by = | rank = [[Bishop]] | birth_name = Gone Benjamin Devasahayam | birth_date = {{Birth date|1925|08|23}} | birth_place = [[Telangana]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1996|08|20|1925|08|23}} | death_place = [[Secunderabad]], [[Telangana]] | buried = [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Wesley Cemetery, Bhoiguda, [[Secunderabad]], [[Telangana]] | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = [[Indian people|Indian]] | religion = [[Christianity]] | parents = [[Smt.]] Lydia (Mother) and
[[Sri]] G. Benjamin (Father) | occupation = [[Priesthood]] | previous_post =[[Pastor]], [[Diocese of Medak]], [[Church of South India]] {{small|(1956-1982)}} | education =[[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]], [[Master of Arts|M.A.]], | alma_mater = [[United Theological College, Bangalore]],
[[McCormick Theological Seminary]], [[Chicago]] | motto = | signature = | signature_alt = | coat_of_arms = | coat_of_arms_alt = | feast_day = | venerated = | saint_title = | beatified_date = | beatified_place = | beatified_by = | canonized_date = | canonized_place = | canonized_by = | attributes = | patronage = | shrine = | suppressed_date = | module = | other = }} {{Portal|Methodism}} '''Bishop G. B. Devasahayam''' ''(born 23 August 1925; died 20 August 1996)''[[The Hindu]]'', Hyderabad Edition, ''Death Anniversaries'' August 20, 2016, p.4.'' was the second elected [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Bishop - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese of the Church of South India]] who occupied the ''[[Cathedra]]'' from 1982 through 1987 placed in the [[Church of South India|CSI]]-Wesley Cathedral in [[Karimnagar]] Town in [[Telangana]], [[India]] Devasahayam hailed from the [[Protestant]] [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Diocese of Medak]] which was predominantly a [[Wesleyan Church|Wesleyan Methodist]] congregation initiated by the [[English Wesleyan Mission|Wesleyan Methodist Missionary Society]]P. Y. Luke, J. B. Carman, ''Village Christians and Hindu Culture'' (first published by Lutterworth Press in 1968) ISPCK, New Delhi, 2009, pp.16-17.[https://books.google.com/books?id=YTqM8gCpXI0C&lpg=PA15&dq=Wesleyan%20Methodist%20Missionary%20Society%20medak&pg=PA17#v=onepage&q=Wesleyan%20Methodist%20Missionary%20Society%20medak&f=false] which unionized itself into the [[Church of South India]] that was inaugurated on 20 September 1947Charles Yrigoyen Jr., Susan E. Warrick (Edited), ''Historical Dictionary of Methodism'' (Third edition), Scarecrow, Lanham, 2013, p.197.[https://books.google.com/books?id=aWUYAgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA197&dq=20%20september%201947%20CSI&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=20%20september%201947%20CSI&f=false] at the [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[St. George's Cathedral, Chennai]]. After Devasahayam discerned his avocation towards priesthood, then Bishop, [[Frank Whittaker]] sent him to the [[Protestant]] Regional Theologiate in [[Bangalore]] for ministerial formation during 1952-1956 after which Devasahayam was ordained and began ministering in the ecclesiastical jurisdiction of the [[Diocese of Medak]] during the successive bishoprics of [[Frank Whittaker]], [[Eber Priestley]], [[H. D. L. Abraham]] and [[B. G. Prasada Rao]]. After nearly 25 years of pastoral ministry, Devasahayam contested the bishopric in the adjoining [[Diocese of Karimnagar]] and was declared elected by the [[Church of South India Synod]] resulting in his appointment as the second [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]] where he began his bishopric from 1982 and continued to build up the ministry and evangelism[[P. Surya Prakash]], ''Karimnagar Diocese 133 years and Beyond: Church of South India Karimnagar Diocese - A Story of Transformation (1879-2012), 2012, p.5.[https://oimts.files.wordpress.com/2013/09/2013-2-prakash.pdf] in the diocese following the precedent set by his predecessor [[B. Prabhudass]]. In 1987, after shepherding the bishopric for nearly six years, Devasahayam announced his resignation from the ecclesiastical office of the Bishop citing health reasons and vacated the ''[[Cathedra]]'' resulting in ''[[sede vacante]]''. The sudden turn of events took the ecclesiastical circles by storm making the [[Church of South India Synod]] led by Moderator [[I. Jesudason]] and Deputy Moderator [[Victor Premasagar|P. Victor Premasagar]] to huddle and take steps to fill the ''[[sede vacante]]'' caused by the resignation of Devasahayam. ==Ministerial formation== ===Graduate=== Devasahayam pursued spiritual studies at the [[United Theological College, Bangalore]] affiliated to India's firstSankar Ray, The Hindu (Business Line), 11 April 2008 ''Almost a century later, the charter was endorsed officially under the Bengal Govt Act IV of 1918. '' Internet, accessed 30 November 2008. [http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/life/2008/04/11/stories/2008041150100400.htm] University, the [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]]'' {a University under Section 2 (f) of the [[University Grants Commission (India)|University Grants Commission]] Act, 1956}''The [[Senate of Serampore College (University)]] is a University within the meaning of Section 2 (f) of the UGC Act, 1956 under which a University means a University established or incorporated by or under a Central Act, a Provincial Act or a State Act, and includes any such institution as may, in consultation with the University concerned, be recoginsed by the Commission in accordance with the regulations made in this behalf under this Act. The UGC took the opinion that the Senate fell under the purview of Section 2 (f) of the said Act since ''The Serampore College Act, 1918'' was passed by the Government of West Bengal. with degree-granting authority validated by a Danish Charter and ratified by the [[Government of West Bengal]]. Devasahayam studied at the seminary for four years from 1952-1956K. M. Hiwale (Compiled), ''Directory of the United Theological College 1910-1997'', Bangalore, 1997. p.26 during the Principalships of [[Max Hunter Harrison]] and [[Joshua Russell Chandran]] leading to award of [[Bachelor of Divinity]] during the annual convocation of the University held in 1957 during the Registrarship of William Stewart. ===Postgraduate=== After a decade and half of ecclesiastical ministry, the [[Diocese of Medak]] led by [[H. D. L. Abraham]] sent Devasahayam to the [[McCormick Theological Seminary]],''Minutes of the General Assembly of the United Presbyterian Church in the United States of America'', Part 1, United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. General Assembly Office of the General Assembly, 1972, p.1201. [https://books.google.com/books?id=kcMcAQAAMAAJ&q=gone+benjamin+devasahayam&dq=gone+benjamin+devasahayam&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMIr7Xg8rvNxwIVUAiOCh0XtwDL] [[Chicago]] in 1971 to upgrade his academics where he enrolled for a [[Master of Arts]][[Mar Aprem Mooken]], ''Indian Christian Who is Who'', Bombay Parish Church of the East, Bombay, 1983, p.41. [https://books.google.com/books?id=u2s5AAAAMAAJ&q=g.b.devasahayam&dq=g.b.devasahayam&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAWoVChMIwNSW_MDNxwIVkguOCh2Dug9s] programme leading to the award of the [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] by the seminary. ==Ecclesiastical ministry== ===Pastorate=== After a 4-year ministerial formation at the [[Protestant]] Regional Theologiate in [[Bangalore]] during 1952-1956, Devasahayam was ordained as a [[Pastor]] by [[Frank Whittaker]], the first [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Medak Diocese|Medak]] following which he began to minister parishes in the ecclesiastical jurisdiction of the [[Diocese of Medak]] pastoring in [[Secunderabad]], [[Nizamabad, Telangana|Nizamabad]], Dudgaon in Telangana region of the erstwhile [[Andhra Pradesh]] state. ===Bishopric=== In 1982 when the first [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]], [[B. Prabhudass]] vacated the ''[[Cathedra]]'' on attaining superannuation, the [[Church of South India Synod]] announced the conduction of fresh elections to fill in the ''[[sede vacante]]'', following which Devasahayam from the adjoining [[Diocese of Medak]] was declared elected and appointed to the bishopric leading to his consecration in 1982 by [[I. Jesudasan]] then Moderator of the [[Church of South India Synod]] who principally consecrated Devasahayam as [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]] in the presence of Sundar Clarke, the Deputy Moderator and co-consecrator. As Bishop, Devasahayam took part in the biennial conclaves of the [[Church of South India Synod]]s of 1984 and 1986 held at [[Secunderabad]] and [[Trivandrum]] respectively. In 1987, Devasahayam vacated the Bishopric on account of health reasons resulting in an unexpected ''[[sede vacante]]'' very much similar to the present papacy of [[Pope Benedict XVI]] who resigned citing health reasons in 2013. The [[Church of South India Synod]] filled the ''[[sede vacante]]'' by announcing the appointment of [[K. E. Swamidass]], who incidentally was a companion of Devasahayam during his seminary studies in Bangalore. ==Governor== As [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]], Devasahayam was ''[[ex officio]]'' member of the Board of Governors of the near-[[ecumenical]] [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], a [[Protestant]] Regional Theologiate situated in [[Hyderabad]] comprising a few [[Protestant]] societies, the [[Wesleyans]], [[Methodists]], [[Lutherans]], [[Baptists]], [[Congregationalists]], and the [[Anglicans]]. Devasahayam represented the [[Karimnagar Diocese]] which was again a [[Wesleyan]] congregation from 1982 through 1987 on the Board of Governors coinciding with the successive cycle of Principalships held by [[Convention of Baptist Churches of Northern Circars]] and the [[Samavesam of Telugu Baptist Churches]] led by [[Reverend|The Rev.]] K. David, [[Ph.D.]] ([[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]]) and [[Reverend|The Rev.]] [[Suppogu Joseph|S. Joseph]], [[D.Th.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]) respectively. ==Retirement and death== After Devasahayam sought early retirement from the bishopric in 1987 on account of health reasons, he returned to the [[Diocese of Medak]] and resided in [[Secunderabad]]. In 1992 Devasahayam took part in the consecration of the [[Old Testament]] Scholar [[S. John Theodore]] as the fourth [[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]] along with his predecessor [[B. Prabhudass]] as well as [[K. E. Swamidass]] his successor.''National Council of Churches Review'', Volume 113, National Christian Council of India, 1993, p.193. [https://books.google.com/books?id=PgrZAAAAMAAJ&q=t.b.d.prakasa+rao&dq=t.b.d.prakasa+rao&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisyr7KtbHKAhVSHo4KHaPHBo8Q6AEIGzAA] Devasahayam continued to minister in the [[Diocese of Medak]] until his death on 20 August 1996. {{S-start}} {{S-rel}} {{Succession box | before=[[B. Prabhudass]], [[Church of South India|CSI]]
1978-1982| title=[[Church of South India|CSI]]-[[Bishop]] - in - [[Karimnagar Diocese|Karimnagar]]
[[Church of South India]] |after=[[K. E. Swamidass]], [[Church of South India|CSI]]

'''Gross metropolitan product''' ('''GMP''') is a monetary [[Measurement in economics|measure]] of the value of all final goods and services produced within a [[metropolitan statistical area]] during a specified period (''e.g.'', a quarter, a year). GMP estimates are commonly used to compare the relative economic performance among such areas.
==United States== GMP is calculated annually by the [[Bureau of Economic Analysis]] within the [[United States Department of Commerce]].<ref name="pbm09">[http://pacific.bizjournals.com/pacific/stories/2009/09/21/daily51.html Honolulu economy 51st largest in U.S.] September 25, 2009. ''[[Pacific Business News]]''</ref> This is done only for metropolitan areas and not for [[Micropolitan Statistical Area|micropolitan areas]], metropolitan divisions and [[Combined Statistical Area|combined statistical areas]], and BEA economic areas.<ref>[https://www.bea.gov/regional/ Regional Economic Accounts] October 15, 2012. ''[[Bureau of Economic Analysis]]''</ref>
==See also== * [[List of metropolitan areas in the European Union by GDP]] * [[List of metropolitan areas in the United States by GMP]]

[[Human trafficking]] in Argentina is the illegal trade in persons for purposes of reproductive slavery, [[sexual exploitation]], [[forced labor]], organ removal, or any form of modern [[slavery]].
It is an international crime against humanity and a violates human rights. It is considered a modern form of slavery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acnur.org/secciones/index.php?viewCat=1121|title=404|author=|date=|website=ACNUR: La Agencia de la ONU para los Refugiados|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acnur.org/t3/que-hace/proteccion/trata-y-trafico-de-personas/|title=Trata y tráfico de personas|trans-title=|language=|author=|date=|website=ACNUR: La Agencia de la ONU para los Refugiados|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="esclavosenEuropa">[http://www.monde-diplomatique.es/?url=editorial/0000856412872168186811102294251000/editorial/?articulo=e12ea20f-b219-4659-a8e5-daff3436763a Esclavos en Europa], [[Ignacio Ramonet]], [[Le Monde diplomatique]], Nº: 189 Julio 2011</ref> Worldwide it is ranked third among felony crimes, behind arms and drugs trafficking. It accounts for the movement of more than $32 billion worldwide.<ref name="lanacion">{{Cite web|title=Trata de blancas: el siniestro negocio de la esclavitud sexual|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/976393-trata-de-blancas-el-siniestro-negocio-de-la-esclavitud-sexual|work=La Nación|author=Gustavo Barco |access-date=20 March 2012|date=6 January 2008|language=Spanish |trans-title=Trafficking in women: the sinister business of sexual slavery}}</ref> A United Nations international protocol against human trafficking has been signed by 117 different countries, among them Argentina.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://treaties.un.org/Pages/ViewDetails.aspx?src=TREATY&mtdsg_no=XVIII-12-a&chapter=18&lang=en|title=United Nations Treaty Collection|author=|date=|website=UN.org|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> This treaty obligates the countries that are party to it to prevent and combat human trafficking and to assist and protect the victims of it. It also encourages countries to cooperate among themselves to achieve these objectives.
In Argentina this crime is punishable by law. There are many laws that cover this problem, but the crime continues to occur. An important legal development in this area was the enactment of law number 26.364,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acnur.org/t3/fileadmin/scripts/doc.php?file=biblioteca/pdf/6314|title=Law number 26.364|author=|date=|website=acnur.org|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> which tries to achieve what this international protocol seeks<ref name="Ley">{{Cite web|title=PREVENCIÓN Y SANCIÓN DE LA TRATA DE PERSONAS Y ASISTENCIA A SUS VÍCTIMAS|url=http://www.acnur.org/t3/fileadmin/scripts/doc.php?file=biblioteca/pdf/6314|language=Spanish |trans-title=Prevention and punishment of trafficking and assistance for its victims|access-date=February 9, 2012}}</ref> and provides penalties of 3 to 15 years in prison.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Cristina promulgó la ley sobre Trata de Personas|url=http://www.argentina.ar/_es/pais/C8426-cristina-promulgo-la-ley-sobre-trata-de-personas.php|language=Spanish |trans-title=(President) Christina promulgates a law over trafficking in persons|date=July 5, 2011}}</ref>
Despite being a serious felony, in Argentina there are no official statistics on this crime, only for cases prosecuted. But it is known that the country is a source, transit and destination for trafficking.<ref name="infopico"/> As a means of preventing trafficking, in July 2011 the government issued an order that banned the publication of explicit advertisements of sexual solicitation in the newspapers.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Los avisos de oferta de sexo|url=http://www.diariodecuyo.com.ar/home/new_noticia.php?noticia_id=468915|accessdate=July 16, 2011|author=Diario de Cuyo|language=Spanish |trans-title=Want ads for sex|date=July 8, 2011}}</ref>
A study from 2012 showed that trafficking for sexual exploitation is changing to evade the law, by allowing exploited women to keep their identification documents or allowing them to leave the location of exploitation, to make the trafficking more difficult to prove.<ref name="pagina12"/>
U.S. State Department's [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] placed the country in "Tier 2" in 2017.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/2017/271117.htm|title=Trafficking in Persons Report 2017: Tier Placements|website=www.state.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-01}}</ref>
== Basic elements of trafficking == # '' "Recruitment"''; this can be by deception or by force, and involves a recruiter. # '' "Transport"''; from here to the site of exploitation, the victim is subjected to [[coercion]]. Transfer may be between regions or other countries. Colluding in this process are transporters, corrupt officials, and intermediaries to the trafficking. # The'' "operation"''; here the victim is subjected to exploitation by the [[pimp]] or the operator, who takes a totally illegal right of [[property]] over the victim.<ref Name="UNICEF"/>
== Federal legislation == There are many laws that touch on the theme of trafficking; historically the Ley Palacios of 1913 was the first law in the protection to protect victims of sexual exploitation and slavery, as well as to punish those responsible. It was the first legislation in the entire American continent and signified a great advance in human rights in the country. The [[International Day Against Human Trafficking]] commemorates the enactment of this law.<ref>[http://www.argentina.ar/_es/pais/C2458-dia-internacional-contra-la-trata-de-personas.php Día Internacional contra la Trata de Personas] [Argentina.com.ar], AEN. 25 de Septiembre de 2009</ref>
Argentina, as a signatory to the United Nations [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children]], on April 29, 2008 passed Law 26.364 for the Prevention and Punishment of Trafficking in Persons and Assistance to its Victims. According to the dictates of international protocol and emphasizing care and rights of victims and differentiating between adults and minors. It is in accordance with the codes of international protocol and places emphasis on assistance and rights of victims and their differentiation between adults and minors.
* Law 26.364 defines trafficking as:<ref name=OIM/> {{blockquote|La captación, el transporte y/o traslado — ya sea dentro del país, desde o hacia el exterior—, la acogida o la recepción de personas mayores de dieciocho (18) años de edad, con fines de explotación, cuando mediare engaño, fraude, violencia, amenaza o cualquier medio de intimidación o coerción, abuso de autoridad o de una situación de vulnerabilidad, concesión o recepción de pagos o beneficios para obtener el consentimiento de una persona que tenga autoridad sobre la víctima, aún cuando existiere asentimiento de ésta.|''Tratándose de adultos''.}} {{blockquote|[Translation: The recruitment, transportation and / or moving — whether it is within the country or to or from the exterior, harboring or receipt of persons over the age of eighteen (18) years of age, for the purpose of exploitation, when deception, fraud, violence, threat, or any form of intimidation or coercion, abuse of authority or of a position of vulnerability, giving or receiving of payments or benefits to achieve the consent of a person having control over the victim, even when there is consent of the victim.|''In the case of adults''.]}} {{blockquote|Se entiende por trata de menores el ofrecimiento, la captación, el transporte y/o traslado —ya sea dentro del país, desde o hacia el exterior—, la acogida o la recepción de personas menores de dieciocho (18) años de edad, con fines de explotación. Existe trata de menores aún cuando no mediare engaño, fraude, violencia, amenaza o cualquier medio de intimidación o coerción, abuso de autoridad o de una situación de vulnerabilidad, concesión o recepción de pagos o beneficios para obtener el consentimiento de una persona que tenga autoridad sobre la víctima. El asentimiento de la víctima de trata de personas menores de dieciocho (18) años no tendrá efecto alguno.|''En caso de menores''.}} {{blockquote|[Translation: It is meant by trafficking in minors the recruitment, transportation and / or transfer, whether within the country or to and from abroad—, harboring or receipt of persons under eighteen (18) years of age, with the purpose of exploitation. Trafficking of minors exists even when there is no medium of deception, fraud, violence, threat, or any form of intimidation or coercion, abuse of authority or of a position of vulnerability, giving or receiving of payments or benefits to achieve the consent of a person having control on the victim. The consent of a victim of trafficking in persons under eighteen (18) years shall have no effect.|''In the case of minors''.]}}
* Victims can not be punished for committing any offense that is a direct result of being trafficked. In the case of foreigners, no sanctions are applied nor can their contracts be voided because of infractions of immigration legislation if the violations are due trafficking.<ref name=Ufase>{{Cite web|title=Oficina de Rescate y Acompañamiento a Personas Damnificadas por el Delito de Trata de Personas|url=http://www.jus.gob.ar/areas-tematicas/trata-de-personas.aspx|language=Spanish |trans-title=Rescue and Support Office for People Harmed by the Crime of Trafficking in Persons|access-date=March 21, 2012}}</ref> * This law sets criminal and procedural rules, with penalties of 3–6 years in the case of trafficking of adults and 4 to 10 years if there are aggravating circumstances such as:<ref name=ley>{{cite web|url=http://www.asapmi.org.ar/publicaciones/legislacion/articulo.asp?id=451|title=Ley 26.364 - Prevención y Sanción de la Trata de Personas y Asistencia a sus Víctimas.|trans-title=|language=|author=|date=|website=www.Asapmi.org.ar|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> # The person who commits the crime is parent or grandparent, spouse, related in a direct line, brother, guardian, person living, tutor, in charge of education or a caretaker, minister of any religion recognized or not, or public official; # The act was committed by three or more people in an organized manner; # There were three or more victims.
== Victims == Trafficking generates victims who in the majority of cases live under inhuman conditions; to be a victim of trafficking involves slavery, in which the trafficker gains a totally illegal right of property right over the victim or reduces her to the level of indentured servitude for the purpose of economic exploitation. In Argentina the most common victims of forced labor are in underground sweatshops are textile or as farm laborers and in other cases domestic workers. As for sexual exploitation that principally affects women, adolescents, and children, they are mostly found in the country's brothels.<ref name="infopico">{{Cite web|title=Trata de personas, Argentina es lugar de origen, de tránsito y de destino|url=http://www.infopico.com/social/4864-trata-de-personas-argentina-es-lugar-de-origen-de-transito-y-de-destino|language=Spanish|trans-title=Trafficking in persons, Argentina is location of transit and destination|access-date=February 9, 2012}}</ref><ref name="UNICEF">{{Cite web|title=¿De qué se trata la de niños, niñas y adolescentes?|url=http://www.unicef.org/argentina/spanish/FolletoTrata(final).pdf|author=[[Unicef]]|language=Spanish |trans-title=What about trafficking in girls, boys, and adolescents?}}</ref>
=== Forced labor === Forced labor includes a variety of trades, but the sectors most affected are rural and textile labor.
==== Textile industry ==== According to the National Institute of Statistics and Censuses (INDEC – Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Censos), unregistered labor in apparel approaches 75%. The greater number of these workers are black, which promotes the spread of forced labor. According to Gustavo Vera, president of the cooperative La Alameda (which represents and defends textile workers), "We know that there are about 3,000 underground sweatshops in the Federal Capital" and he adds "There are also some 15,000 underground sweatshops in the first tier of the Buenos Aires suburbs and several thousand more in Greater Buenos Aires, Rosario, Mendoza and Cordoba. These workshops include a population of about 200,000 people who are reduced to forced labor or slave labor, which is the same as forced labor but worse, because the will of the workers is controlled 24 hours a day by the employer." <ref>{{Cite web|title=Autoridades argentinas investigan fábricas textiles ilegales |url=http://infosurhoy.com/cocoon/saii/xhtml/es/features/saii/features/main/2010/06/10/feature-02 |author=Ezequiel Vinacour |work=Infosurhoy.com |language=Spanish |trans-title=Argentine authorities investigate illegal textile factories |date=June 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121210085616/http://infosurhoy.com/cocoon/saii/xhtml/es/features/saii/features/main/2010/06/10/feature-02 |archivedate=December 10, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
According to the [[Bureau of International Labor Affairs]], Argentina is classified among the 74 countries in which [[child labor]] and [[forced labor]] is still practiced today. The Bureau's ''[[List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/list-of-goods/|title=List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor|author=|date=|website=DOL.gov|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> mentions "garments" as one of 11 other products in Argentina. Furthermore, in one of its reports on the worst forms of child labor, The [[United States Department of Labor|U.S. Department of Labor]] states that "Argentina has not adopted a list of hazardous occupations that are prohibited to children, and appears to lack programs that target working children in all relevant sectors."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/reports/child-labor/argentina.htm|title=Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor - Argentina|author=|date=30 September 2016|website=DOL.gov|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref>
==== Rural ==== In Argentina, one of the first protections of the farm laborer was born in 1940 with the enactment of the Estatuto del Peón <nowiki>[Statute of farm laborers]</nowiki> which gave wage laborers (jornaleros) all the rights of workers (trabajadores). Later, complementary laws were added. The government of Cristina Kirchner signed the conventions of the [[International Labour Organization]] (ILO) prohibiting the forced recruitment of manual labor for the rural labor force. However, there still exist recruiting networks that through deception or physical coercion recruit people who are typically in a vulnerable situation. And they are recruited from marginal rural areas of Santiago del Estero, Chaco, Tucuman, Catamarca and Jujuy and from migrant workers from bordering countries such as Chile, Bolivia, and Paraguay. And then they are taken to areas where they do hard labor and live in subhuman conditions. These situations violate the [[American Convention on Human Rights|Protocol of San Salvador]] treaty and [[Safety and Health in Agriculture Convention, 2001|International Labour Conference Convention 184]].<ref>{{Cite web|title=Trabajo forzado en el mundo agrario: una cara oculta del bicentenario argentino|url=http://www.pacarinadelsur.com/home/abordajes-y-contiendas/282-trabajo-forzado-en-el-mundo-agrario-una-cara-oculta-del-bicentenario-argentino|author=Daniel Cieza (Catedrático de las Universidades de Buenos Aires y La Plata|language=Spanish |trans-title=Forced labor in the agrarian world: a dark face of the Argentine bicentennial )}}</ref>
=== Sexual abuse ===
==== History ==== Sexual exploitation was born in the [[Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata]] before the country was even created.<ref name=historia>{{Cite web|title=HISTORIA DE LA TRATA DE PERSONAS EN ARGENTINA COMO PERSISTENCIA DE LA ESCLAVITUD.|url=http://www.mseg.gba.gov.ar/Trata/HISTORIA.pdf|author=Dr. Raúl A. Schnabel|work=Dirección General de Registro de Personas Desaparecidas|language=Spanish |trans-title=History of the trafficking of persons in Argentina as persistence of slavery}}</ref> After independence in 1875, a law was made regulating prostitution, preventing prostitution of minors, but allowing it if the children were initiated early into this activity.
In the late nineteenth century "white slavery" rings were established that provided women from Central Europe and Russia, who were sold in a sham marriage to a ruffian. They sought to escape poverty and religious persecution that they suffered. And in this country they were forced into prostitution or sold to another pimp.<ref name=historia/> In the early twentieth century, these trafficking organizations tightened their ties with power. This was in order to be protected by law or to avoid problems in case of breaking laws or deception. Because of their great accumulation of wealth through "kickbacks", they accomplished their mission.<ref name=historia/> Among the customers it is possible to highlight periods of intense European migration that brought primarily single men as main consumers of trafficking, although upper middle class Argentinians also had a high level use of prostitution. By the early twentieth century there were two major international trafficking rings.
MILIEU, a trafficking organization of French origin, and La Migdal, or [[Zwi Migdal]], of Jewish origin, formerly called the Varsovia (Warsaw) Jewish Mutual Aid Society – This last organization came to an end in 1929 when [[Raquel Liberman]], one of thousands of Polish immigrants enslaved in brothels, reported Zwi Migdal to the authorities.<ref name="clarin">{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/diario/2004/03/13/s-05901.htm|title=Zwi Migdal: filman la historia de la mafia polaca en la Argentina|first=|last=Clarin.com|date=|website=www.Clarin.com|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> The complaint was taken by a judge, Manuel Rodriguez Ocampo. Especially since another 150 previous complaints were not successful either because of violence against the accusers or police and judicial corruption. This trial against the organization made it possible to make public the treatment suffered by victims.<ref name="historia"/>
After several periods of closure and opening of brothels, from June 24, 1965, Law 16.666 was put into effect that the practice of prostitution is open and not subject to any form of regulation, this law is in effect to the present day.
In practice, this criminal activity is organized on a grand scale and is frequently associated with the [[illegal drug trade]] and with [[arms trafficking]]. Much of this crime is organized on a global level.
==== Current status ==== At present, Argentina is a source, transit, and destination location for trafficking, which means that the victims can be Argentinian or from other countries, that they go through this country, and that some have this as the destination to be illegally exploited.<ref name="infopico"/>
"Reclutadores" (recruiters) capture the victims through deception or abduction, assisted by "marcadores" (markers) who pick the victims. Then the circle closes with the "proxenetas" ([[pimp]]s) who get their profit from the sexual exploitation of victims. And finally the "regentes" (managers) or madames of brothels. There are also carriers and secondary dealers concerned with protecting this whole criminal system. In some cases there is some kind of collusion between members of the police, judges, and politicians.<ref name="lanacion"/>
The province of the country in which the most women are recruited is Entre Rios, followed by Misiones, Corrientes, Chaco, Santa Fe and Tucuman; usually victims are rotated through brothels across the whole country. The list of destinations includes Buenos Aires and Cordoba, at the head of the list of destinations chosen by the rings, along with La Pampa, Chubut, Santa Cruz and Tierra del Fuego. There are also links to international rings, especially the route to Spain,<ref name="santa rosa">{{Cite web|title=TRATA DE MUJERES EN ARGENTINA |trans-title=| language=Spanish | url=http://santarosa.gov.ar/genero/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56:trata-de-mujeres-en-argentina&catid=46:articulos-recomendados&Itemid=72 |author=Paloma Bazan |work=SantaRosa.gov.ar |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310135130/http://santarosa.gov.ar/genero/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56%3Atrata-de-mujeres-en-argentina&catid=46%3Aarticulos-recomendados&Itemid=72 |archivedate=2012-03-10 |df= }}</ref> where young Tucuman women were rescued.<ref name="lanacion"/>
==== Recruitment ==== There are many recruiting methods but all are either "soft", based on fraud and deception, or "hard", based directly on kidnapping the victims.
*Kidnapping: in this crime women are identified and marked. Later they are kidnapped from off the street, they are drugged and transported to a place where they are repeatedly violated for the purpose of sexually exploiting them later. Those who offer resistance are threatened with harming or killing her family.<ref name="santa rosa"/> *Deception: in which recruiters take advantage of the poverty or defenselessness of the victim with false offers of employment, moving the victim to another province or country, after which she finds she is to be sexually exploited.<ref name="santa rosa"/>
There are also cases in which the victim has agreed to work in the sex trade, but then finds out the working and living conditions fall within the category of trafficking. Sometimes these victims only recognize the exploitation after intensive psychological assistance.<ref name=infopico/><ref name=notio>{{Cite web|author=Joaquín Garau |title=¿Cómo es la Argentina de la Trata de Personas? |url=http://notio.com.ar/tus-notas/como-es-la-argentina-de-la-trata-de-personas-2509 |language=Spanish |trans-title=How is Argentina with regard to trafficking in persons: |date=October 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105223145/http://notio.com.ar/tus-notas/como-es-la-argentina-de-la-trata-de-personas-2509 |archivedate=2011-11-05 |df= }}</ref>
==== Recent studies ====
A recent study in 2012 of court cases of the Unidad Fiscal de Asistencia en Secuestros Extorsivos y Trata de Personas [Fiscal Unit of Assistance in Kidnappings and Trafficking in Persons](UFASE) and the Instituto de Estudios Comparados en Ciencias Penales y Sociales [Institute for Comparative Studies in Criminal and Social Sciences] (INECIP) revealed that trafficking for sexual exploitation is mutating into new forms of subjugation of women, to make it more difficult to prove the existence of slavery in bordellos and thus evading the law. This is a result of the enactment of Law 26.364 in April 2008 that strongly penalizes this offense. The victims have their documents in their possession and in many cases are allowed to leave the sites of exploitation, but the subjugation continues to function in another way. Furthermore, the report shows collusion between state, local, police, and judicial entities that "legitimizes the activity and leads to its habituation." Some 72% of cases are enslaved in nightclubs like ''whiskerías'' (undercover brothels), pubs, or pool halls, all enabled by the municipalities, and the other 22% in private apartments.<ref name=pagina12>{{Cite web|title=Nuevos métodos para eludir la ley|url=http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/elpais/1-191441-2012-04-09.html|accessdate=April 10, 2012|work=[[Página 12]]|date=April 9, 2012|language=Spanish |trans-title=New methods to elude the law}}</ref>
=== Underage victims === Worldwide, close to 2.5 million people are victims of some form of trafficking. Between 22% and 50% are girls and boys. The exact figure is unknown because trafficking in children is usually hidden; for this reason, reliable data cannot be obtained. Many of these situations occur within cities or urban areas. For example, trafficking for the purposes of [[sexual exploitation]] occurs with girls and boys working on city streets. Many rural children from rural areas are moved to the cities by the traffickers.<ref name=Unicef-pdf>{{Cite web|author=Unicef|title=ESTADO MUNDIAL DE LA INFANCIA 2012, Niñas y niños en un mundo urbano|url=http://www.unicef.org/argentina/spanish/SOWC-2012-Main-Report-LoRes-PDF_SP_01052012.pdf|accessdate=April 30, 2012|work=[[Unicef]]|language=Spanish |trans-title=STATE OF CHILDHOOD 2012, Girls and boys in an urban world}}</ref>
According to the Department of State of the United States, that which occurs in the world also occurs in Argentina. Children come from northern provinces, or from bordering countries like Bolivia, Paraguay, and Brazil. Areas with a triple border are a major focus of child trafficking and [[child labor]], especially of children living in border areas and bordering countries. These end up in urban centers of central and south of the country, where [[child sex tourism]] is promoted. Others are victims of forced labor in underground sweatshops and agricultural enterprises.<ref name="clarin informe">{{Cite web|title=Sociedad Trata de personas: Crítico informe de EE.UU. sobre trata de personas en Argentina|url=http://www.clarin.com/sociedad/Critico-informe-EEUU-personas-Argentina_0_423557735.html|work=Periódico El Clarín|date=February 8, 2011|language=Spanish |trans-title=Society/: Trafficking in persons: U.S. report critical on human trafficking in Argentina}}</ref>
Under the new Argentine law, child trafficking is punishable by the maximum penalty for this offense. In addition, penalties can be increased if there are aggravating factors.
=== Interviews about trafficking === Narrative on trafficking for sexual exploitation:<ref name="OIM">{{cite web|url=http://campus.oimconosur.org/descarga/sensibilizacion/que+es+la+trata+de+personas.pdf|title=Хостинг VPS аренда сервера - Интернет Хостинг Центр|trans-title=|language=|author=|date=|website=campus.Oimconosur.org|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref> {{cita|“Me ofrecieron empleo en un restaurante en la capital,a casi 400 km.de mi casa. Como en mi pueblo no había trabajo, acepté. Me adelantaron $200 y me dieron el pasaje en ómnibus. Cuando llegué a la dirección que me habían dado, me dijeron que el restaurante era a unas cuadras, y me llevaron en auto. Pero cuando llegamos, no era una parrilla: era una whiskería. Me encerraron, me pegaron, me violaron y me obligaron a prostituirme. Además, me dijeron que si le decía algo a alguien, esto mismo se lo harían a mis hijas, ya que sabían dónde vivían... Nunca pensé que me pudiera pasar una cosa así…”}} {{cita|[Translation: "I was offered employment in a restaurant in the capital, nearly 400 km from my house. As in my village there was no work, I accepted. They gave me an advance of $200 and bus fare. When I arrived at the address they had given me, I was told that the restaurant was a few blocks away, and brought me there by car. But when we arrived, it was not a grill: it was a ''whiskería'' (undercover brothel). They locked me up, beat me, raped me and forced me into prostitution. In addition, I was told that if I said anything to anyone, they would do the same thing to my daughters, since they knew where they lived ... I never would have thought that such a thing could happen to me ... "]
|Source: Organización Internacional para las Migraciones [International Organization for Migration]}}
Narrative of labor exploitation:<ref name="OIM"/> {{cita|“Un día por la radio escuché que un fabricante pedía costureros para su taller en Buenos Aires. En Santa Cruz (Bolivia), me entrevisté con una señora que me dijo que pagaban un peso con cincuenta la prenda, con casa y comida. Ellos pagaban el traslado, y después me lo iban descontando. Mi pasaje salió 120 dólares. Viajamos mi mujer, yo, y unas seis personas más. De la terminal de micros de Retiro nos llevaron directo al taller, y el dueño se quedó con nuestros documentos. El taller tiene dos habitaciones bien grandes, con unas 15 máquinas. Allí trabajamos, comemos y vivimos todos, incluso hay gente con niños pequeños. Trabajamos de lunes a sábado al mediodía, desde las siete de la mañana hasta la una de la madrugada del día siguiente. Al que se cansa o quiere dormir, el dueño lo amenaza con no pagarle nada, con “cagarlo a palos por vago”, o con denunciarlo a la policía para que lo deporten. Las puertas del taller están cerradas con llave, y la puerta de calle también. Ayer cuando le pedí lo que me debía, porque quería mandar plata a mi familia, me dijo que no me debía nada, me gritó que si lo seguía jodiendo llamaba a los de migraciones y me agarró a las patadas; a mi señora también le pegó.”}}
{{cita|[Translation: "One day I heard on the radio that a manufacturer was asking for sewing workers for their workshop in Buenos Aires. In Santa Cruz (Bolivia), I interviewed with a woman who told me they were paying one peso per fifty garments, with room and board. They would pay for the transportation and later give me a discount. My passage turned out to be $120. We traveled together: my wife, myself, and some six people more. From Retiro, the main terminal for long-distance bus travel in Buenos Aires, they took us straight to the shop and the owner kept our documents. The workshop has two rather large rooms, with about 15 machines. That was where we all worked, ate, and lived, including even people with small children. We worked from Monday to Saturday at noon, from seven o'clock in the morning until one o'clock in the morning of the next day. If anyone gets tired or wants to sleep, the owner threatens to not pay us anything, to "beat the crap out of us for being lazy," or to denounce us to the police so they would deport us. The shop doors are locked and the door to the street as well. Yesterday when I asked what he owed me, because I wanted to send money to my family, he told me he didn't owe me anything, he shouted at me that if I kept screwing around he would call immigration and he grabbed me kicking, he also hit my wife."]|
Source: Organización Internacional para las Migraciones <nowiki>[International Organization for Migration]</nowiki>}}
== Court cases ==
=== Case of Marita Veron === {{main|Marita Veron}} {{See also|Susana Trimarco}} One of the more well known cases in Argentina is that of Marita Veron, which was brought to court in 2012 after an intensive search and collection of evidence, where part of the network of this country's web of trafficking for sexual exploitation was discovered.
It is known that she left her home on April 3, 2002, and three days later, she was found by police while escaping from a sex party that seems to have been her first destination; she was put on a bus with a group traveling in the direction of Tucuman but never arrived. Later, a witness saw her in one of three Rioja brothels, which the Appeals Chamber of Tucumán described as "places intended for the practice of prostitution where there is a systematic recruitment of women including by means deprivation of liberty." Since then there has been no more information obtained on the whereabouts of Marita.
Marita's mother Susana Trimarco, the principal impulse behind the investigation, has managed to rescue more than 20 women who were victims of trafficking. The Maria de los Angeles Foundation rescues and helps victims of trafficking.
The trial over the disappearance of Marita began on February 8, 2012, and indicted 13 people, 7 men and 6 women, who are linked to the kidnapping and to the promotion of prostitution. It brought together more than 150 witnesses.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Comenzó el juicio de Marita Verón, un caso emblemático de trata de personas|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1447059-arranca-el-juicio-de-marita-veron-un-caso-emblematico-de-trata-de-personas|accessdate=March 16, 2012|language=Spanish |trans-title=The opening of the trial of Marita Veron, an emblematic case of human trafficking|date=February 8, 2012}}</ref> The trial ended on December 11, 2012, and all indicted people were absolved, the mother of Marita Veron will impulse a political trial against the magistrate.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1536071-conmocion-sin-culpables-en-el-juicio-por-marita-veron|title=Conmoción: sin culpables en el juicio por Marita Verón|author=|date=|website=LaNacion.com.ar|access-date=15 October 2017}}</ref>
=== UFASE's statistics === According to statistics taken from August 22, 2008, to March 7, 2012, by the Fiscal Assistance Unit of Kidnappings and Trafficking (UFASE – Unidad Fiscal de Asistencia en Secuestros Extorsivos y Trata de Personas) responsible for assisting the Argentine fiscal units in the processing of kidnappings and trafficking court cases. Some 64% of court cases were for trafficking for purposes of sexual exploitation, while the percentages for trafficking for labor exploitation were 5% rural, 1% textile, and 1% begging. As for sexual exploitation, 77% of the victims were female, 19% male, and 4% transgender. In 70% of cases, the method of recruitment was by "promises of employment", 8% by exploiting the victim's family problems and 8% inducement by romantic relationship, and 3% of cases by the delivery by a family member or acquaintance. Some 52% had no freedom of movement and 45% experienced violence. With regard to the nationality of the victims, 31% were Bolivian, 28% Argentinian, 21% Paraguayan, 10% Dominican, 5% Peruvian, 3% Colombian, and 2% Uruguayan. Source countries for recruitment were 83% in Argentina, 12% in Paraguay, and 1% in Bolivia, while the destination country was 94% for Argentina, 4% Paraguay, and 2% Chile.<ref>{{Cite web|author=Ministerio Público de la Nación, Unidad Fiscal de Asistencia en Secuestros Extorsivos y Trata de Personas |title=INFORME SOBRE PRIMERA ETAPA DEL RELEVAMIENTO DE CASOS JUDICIALIZADOS DE TRATA DE PERSONAS. |url=http://www.mpf.gov.ar/ics-wpd/DocumentosWeb/LinksNoticias/informe_nea.pdf |language=Spanish |trans-title=REPORT ON FIRST STAGE OF SURVEY OF PROSECUTION OF CASES OF HUMAN TRAFFICKING |access-date=March 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903062612/http://www.mpf.gov.ar/ics-wpd/DocumentosWeb/LinksNoticias/informe_nea.pdf |archivedate=September 3, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author=UFASE |title=Trata de Personas, Recolección de Datos Estadísticos |url=http://www.mpf.gov.ar/index.asp?page=Accesos/Ufase/ufase3.asp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805082633/http://www.mpf.gov.ar/index.asp?page=Accesos/Ufase/ufase3.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 5, 2012 |access-date=March 7, 2012 }}</ref>
== Support programs for victims and others ==
=== Office for Rescue and Caring of Victims of Trafficking === According to the new Law 26.364 that was created in August 2008, the "[http://www.jus.gob.ar/areas-tematicas/trata-de-personas.aspx Oficina de Rescate y Acompañamiento a Personas Damnificadas por el Delito de Trata de Personas] <nowiki>[Office of Rescue and Support for People Harmed by the Crime of Trafficking in Persons]</nowiki>", is under the Chief of Staff of the Ministry of Justice Office. The security forces, professionals in psychology, law, and social work have a similar form. They accompany the victim from the time of their rescue or escape from the place of exploitation and during the investigation of the trafficking crime, later providing support and legal assistance until the moment they give testimony. Victims receive psychological, medical, and legal assistance. Later the victims "testify under conditions of special protection and care"; this can be via a [[Gesell chamber]] or one-way mirror.<ref name=MJD>{{Cite web |author=Ministerio de Justicia y Derechos Humanos |title=Oficina de Rescate y Acompañamiento |url=http://www.jus.gob.ar/areas-tematicas/trata-de-personas/oficina-de-rescate-y-acompa%C3%B1amiento.aspx |language=Spanish |trans-title=Office of Rescue and Support |accessdate=March 21, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309140054/http://www.jus.gob.ar/areas-tematicas/trata-de-personas/oficina-de-rescate-y-acompa%C3%B1amiento.aspx |archivedate=March 9, 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Victims are "not punishable for committing any offense that is a direct result of being trafficked." In the case of foreigners, no sanctions are applied either.<ref name="Ufase"/>
=== Maria de los Angeles Foundation === Fundación María de los Ángeles<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/home.htm|title=Fundación María de los Ángeles|author=|date=|website=FundacionMariaDeLosAngeles.org|access-date=15 October 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814151401/http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/home.htm|archivedate=14 August 2012|df=}}</ref> <nowiki>[Foundation of Maria of the Angels]</nowiki> is a nonprofit organization that fights against the crime of human trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation. The foundation assists victims of sexual exploitation free of charge, and offers legal assistance to victims, counseling for victims and families, and social assistance. It also provides community talks and [[capacity building]] for judges, prosecutors, and police.<ref name="fundacion">{{Cite web|title=La Fundación Misión |url=http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/mision.htm |language=Spanish |trans-title=Mission |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101234746/http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/mision.htm |archivedate=2012-11-01 |df= }}</ref>
It seeks to prosecute applicable cases under Law 26.364 and to provide psychological support to victims so they can overcome the traumatic situations they have lived through.<ref Name="fundacion"/>
The foundation was founded by [[Susana Trimarco]] in 2007 with the help of the Human Rights Secretariat of Tucuman. Since then this group has achieved the filing of more than 800 court cases, and has found and rescued at least 400 women subjected to sex trafficking without their consent.<ref>{{Cite web|title=La madre que se disfrazó de proxeneta para encontrar a su hija|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mundo/noticias/2012/04/120402_argentina_caso_marita_veron_una_decada_vh.shtml|work=[[BBC Mundo]]|language=Spanish |trans-title=The mother who dressed as a pimp to find her daughter}}</ref>
Susana Trimarco is still searching for her daughter [[Marita Veron|Marita]], who fell victim to sex trafficking on April 3, 2002. After investigating the crime of trafficking and its networks, and rescuing many victims, including some under 12 years of age, she decided to create the foundation to help victims and to continue searching for her daughter. The vision of the foundation is to eradicate the trafficking of persons in Argentina.<ref>{{Cite web|title=La Fundación Visión |url=http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/vision.htm |language=Spanish |trans-title=The foundation's vision |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917114331/http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/vision.htm |archivedate=2008-09-17 |df= }}</ref>
The María de los Ángeles foundation has offices based in Tucuman and Buenos Aires [http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/oficinas.htm]. The foundation and Susana Trimarco can count a great many accomplishments and awards.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Trayectoria y Logros|url=http://www.fundacionmariadelosangeles.org/esp/historia.htm|language=Spanish |trans-title=Career and Achievements}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}

(in Spanish)

(in Spanish) * Informe, [http://insightcrime.org/insight-latest-news/item/download/31 La trata sexual en Argentina], Aproximaciones para un análisis de la dinámica del delito, Unidad Fiscal de Asistencia en Secuestros Extorsivos y Trata de Personas, Ministerio Público Fiscal UFASE, Financiado por la Unión Europea. <nowiki>[Approaches to an analysis of the dynamics of crime, Union Fiscal Assistance Unit for assistance in Kidnappings, Extortion, and Human Trafficking, Public Prosecutor UFASE, Funded by the European Union.]</nowiki>(in Spanish) * ''Programa Secretos Argentinos'', [[LRA Radio Nacional|Radio Nacional]] Argentina, [https://archive.is/20121206022009/http://radionacional.com.ar/mediateca/46-radioteatros/31846-secretos-argentinos-caso-marita-veron.html Radioteatro, Caso Marita Verón], ''(Audio y descarga)''. Sobre uno de los casos de trata mas conocido en Argentina. [Program of Argentine Secrets, Argentina National Radio, Radio Drama, The Case of Marita Verón (Audio and download). On one of the most well-known cases of trafficking in Argentina] (in Spanish) * ''Video'', [http://terratv.terra.com.pe/Noticias/Actualidad/Combaten-el-trabajo-forzado-de-bolivianos-en-Argentina_6306-314100.htm Noticia sobre la trata de trabajo esclavo <nowiki>[News about trade in slave labor.]</nowiki>]. En talleres textiles clandestinos. <nowiki>[In underground textile sweatshops.]</nowiki> (in Spanish)

page.title: Incitement to ethnic or racial hatred

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{Expert-subject|Law|date=November 2008}} {{refimprove|date=June 2018}}}} '''[[Incitement]] to racial or [[ethnic hatred]]''' is a crime under the laws of several countries.
==Australia== In [[Australia]], the Racial Hatred Act 1995 amends the [[Racial Discrimination Act 1975]], inserting Part IIA - Offensive Behaviour Because of Race, Colour, National or Ethnic Origin. It does not, however, address the issue of incitement to [[racial hatred]]. The Australian state of [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] has addressed the question, however, with its enactment of the Racial and Religious Tolerance Act 2001.
==Finland== In [[Finland]], agitation against an ethnic group ({{lang-fi|kiihottaminen kansanryhmää vastaan}}) is a crime according to the [[Criminal Code of Finland]]'s (1889/39 and 2011/511) chapter 11, section 10:
'''''Section 10 - Ethnic agitation''' (511/2011)''
''A person who makes available to the public or otherwise spreads among the public or keeps available for the public information, an expression of opinion or another message where a certain group is threatened, defamed or insulted on the basis of its race, skin colour, birth status, national or ethnic origin, religion or belief, sexual orientation or disability or a comparable basis, shall be sentenced for ethnic agitation to a fine or to imprisonment for at most two years.''
'''''Section 10(a) – Aggravated ethnic agitation''' (511/2011)''
''If the ethnic agitation involves incitement or enticement (1) to genocide or the preparation of genocide, a crime against humanity, an aggravated crime against humanity, a war crime, an aggravated war crime, murder, or manslaughter committed for terrorist intent, or (2) to serious violence other than what is referred to in paragraph 1 so that the act clearly endangers public order and safety, and the ethnic agitation also when assessed as a whole is aggravated, the offender shall be sentenced for aggravated ethnic agitation to imprisonment for at least four months and at most four years.''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finlex.fi/fi/laki/ajantasa/1889/18890039001#L11P10|title=FINLEX ® - Ajantasainen lainsäädäntö: Rikoslaki 39/1889|first=Edita Publishing|last=Oy|website=www.finlex.fi|accessdate=22 October 2017}}</ref>
== France == Section 24 of the Press Law of 1881 criminalizes incitement to racial discrimination, hatred, or violence on the basis of one's origin or membership in an ethnic, national, racial, or religious group.<ref>Loi du 29 juillet 1881 sur la liberté de la presse</ref> A criminal code provision deems it an offense to engage in similar conduct via private communication.<ref>Loi n° 90-615 du 13 juillet 1990 tendant à réprimer tout acte raciste, antisémite ou xénophobe</ref>
In 2002, four Muslim organizations filed a complaint against [[Michel Houellebecq]] for stating that Islam was "stupid" and "dangerous" in an interview. The court found that Houellebecq was not immune from the charge on the grounds of literary immunity or freedom of speech, but acquitted him on the grounds that he criticized Islam rather than individual Muslims.<ref>Michael Curtis, ''Jews, Antisemitism, and the Middle East''</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/french-writer-who-called-islam-stupid-cleared-by-judges-140850.html|title=French writer who called Islam 'stupid' cleared by judges|date=23 October 2002|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2002/sep/18/booksnews.islam|title=Calling Islam stupid lands author in court|first=Paul|last=Webster|date=17 September 2002|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> In 2005, politician [[Jean Marie Le Pen]] was convicted of inciting [[racial hatred]], for comments made to Le Monde in 2003 about the consequences of Muslim immigration in France.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2005/02/24/jean-marie-le-pen-condamne-pour-incitation-a-la-haine-raciale_399429_3224.html|title=Jean-Marie Le Pen condamné pour incitation à la haine raciale|date=24 February 2005|publisher=|via=Le Monde}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/archive-news-detail.aspx?pageID=438&n=frances-far-right-leader-le-pen-convicted-of-inciting-racial-hatred-2006-05-12|title=WORLD - France|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/world/le-pen-convicted-of-inciting-racial-hatred-258282.html|title=Le Pen convicted of inciting racial hatred|date=11 May 2006|publisher=}}</ref> Similar complaints were brought in 2015 after he compared Muslim street prayers to the [[Nazi occupation of France]] in 2010, but he was acquitted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/marine-le-pen-cleared-of-inciting-hatred-after-comparing-muslim-prayers-in-the-street-to-nazi-a6774126.html|title=Marine Le Pen cleared of inciting hatred|date=15 December 2015|publisher=}}</ref> In 2008, actress and animal-rights campaigner [[Brigitte Bardot]] was convicted on charges of inciting racial hatred for her criticism concerning the ritual slaughter of sheep during the feast of [[Eid al-Adha]] in a letter to then-Interior Minister [[Nicolas Sarkozy]]. Bardot had been convicted of inciting racial hatred on four other occasions over the previous 11 years for criticizing Muslim immigration.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1731098,00.html|title=Is Brigitte Bardot Bashing Islam?|first=Bruce|last=Crumley|date=15 April 2008|publisher=|via=content.time.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/idINIndia-33883520080603|title=Ex-film star Bardot gets fifth racism conviction|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}}</ref><ref>the feast of Eid al-Adha</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/sep/20/brigitte-bardot-at-80-still-outrageous-outspoken|title=Brigitte Bardot at 80: still outrageous, outspoken and controversial|first=Agnès|last=Poirier|date=20 September 2014|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref>
==Germany== {{Main|Volksverhetzung}}
==United Kingdom== Under the [[law of the United Kingdom]], "incitement to racial hatred" was established as an offence by the provisions of §§ 17-29 of the [[Public Order Act 1986]]. It was first established as a criminal offence in the [[Race Relations Act 1976]]. The [[Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994]] made publication of material that incited racial hatred an [[arrestable offence]].
This offence refers to: * deliberately provoking hatred of a [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial group]] * distributing racist material to the public * making inflammatory public speeches * creating racist websites on the Internet * inciting inflammatory rumours about an individual or an ethnic group, for the purpose of spreading racial discontent.
Laws against incitement to hatred against religions were later established under the [[Racial and Religious Hatred Act 2006]]. However this legislation is not present in Scotland.
== See also == * [[Demagogue]] * [[Hate speech]] * [[International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights]], (Article 20, 2) * [[Public Order Act 1986]] * [[Crime and Disorder Act 1998]] * [[Religious intolerance]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts2000/20000034.htm Government information on the race relations act] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060320081547/http://www.cre.gov.uk/ Commission for racial equality] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060427103141/http://www.crimereduction.gov.uk/toolkits/rh020506.htm Crime Reduction Toolkits: Racist Incidents and Harassment]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Incitement To Ethnic Or Racial Hatred}} [[Category:Race and law]] [[Category:Hate speech]] [[Category:Censorship]] [[fr:Incitation à la haine raciale]] [[ru:Разжигание межнациональной розни]]
