{{Multiple issues|{{Format footnotes|date=June 2011}} {{lead too short|date=November 2017}}}} {{Sociology}} '''Sociology of terrorism''' is an emerging field in [[sociology]] seeking to understand [[terrorism]] as a [[social phenomenon]] and how individuals as well as [[State (polity)|states]] respond to such events. It is not to be confused with [[critical terrorism studies]] which sometimes overlaps with the [[psychology of terrorism]].
==History==
===Pre-September 11 attacks=== After the [[September 11 attacks]], there has been a spike of interest in various sociological traditions related to terrorism, such as [[moral panic]], organizational response and media coverage, and [[counter-terrorism]].
The most comprehensive study into the definition of terrorism comes from a study by Weinberg, Pedahzur and Hirsch-Hoefler (2004) who examined 73 definitions of terrorism from 55 articles and concluded that terrorism is: "a politically motivated tactic involving the threat or use of force or violence in which the pursuit of publicity plays a significant role."<ref>Weinberg, Pedahzur and Hirsch-Hoefler 2004</ref> However, Weinberg ''et al.'' point out that definitions of terrorism often ignore [[Symbolism of terrorism|symbolic aspects of terrorism]]. Due to its focus on symbolism, sociology has a unique vantage point from which to assess [[Fear|terror]].
===Post-September 11 attacks=== Since the September 11 attacks, Mathieu Deflem ([[University of South Carolina]]), S.E. Costanza ([[Central Connecticut State University]]) and John C. Kilburn Jr. ([[Texas A&M International University]]) are among the sociologists to call for the development of a sub-field in sociology related to terrorism. Common topics that are part of the discourse in the sociology of terrorism include: [[military spending]], counter-terrorism, [[immigration]], privacy issues, and the [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]], where within these contexts questions of power, the definition of terrorism, propaganda, nationality, the media, etc. are being deliberated upon.
Early peer-reviewed literature after the September 11 attacks examined policing and citizen responses to terror during the September 11 attacks.<ref>Fischer 2002</ref> It also examined interactions between [[first responder]]s (police, rescue teams, etc.) and communities. Ramirez, Hoopes and Quinlan (2003) rightly predicted that police organizations would change fundamental styles of [[Racial profiling|profiling]] people<ref>Ramirez, Hoopes and Quinlan 2003</ref> and police agencies would alter their [[mission statement]]s after the September 11 attacks. There is strong reason to believe that even the smallest of local police agencies are apt to feel some kind of pressure to deal with the issue of terrorism.<ref>DeLone 2007</ref>
More recent work in the sociology of terrorism field is philosophical and reflective and has focused on issues such as moral panic and over-spending after the September 11 attacks. Costanza and Kilburn (2005), in an article entitled ''Symbolic Security, Moral Panic and Public Sentiment: Toward a sociology of Counterterrorism'' argued that the issue of symbolism is of much importance to understanding the war on terror.<ref>Costanza and Kilburn 2005</ref> Using a classic [[symbolic interactionist]] perspective, they argue that strong public sentiment about the [[homeland security]] issue has driven policy more to superficial threats than real and concrete threats. Others argue that symbolism has led to agency a policy of “[[hypervigilance]]” in agency decision-making that is costly and [[Falsifiability|untestable]].
Some sociologists and legal scholars have contemplated the potential consequences of aggressive (or [[militaristic]]) policing of terror threats that may have negative implications for human rights which are of great interest to sociologists as a matter of [[social justice]]. For instance, in a peer-reviewed article ''Crouching tiger or phantom dragon? Examining the discourse on global cyber-terror'', Helms, Costanza and Johnson (2011) ask if it is possible that media hype at the national level could prompt an unnecessary and systemic over-pursuit of [[cyberterrorism]]. They warn that such overreaction might lead to a "[[killswitch]]" policy which could give the federal government ultimate power over the internet.
Despite the [[Quantitative research|quantitative]] lean of modern sociology; Kilburn, Costanza, Borgeson and Metchik (2011) point out that there are several methodological barbs to effectively and scientifically assessing the effect of homeland security measures.<ref>Kilburn, Costanza, Borgeson and Metchik 2011</ref> In traditional [[criminology]], the most quantitatively amenable starting point for measuring the effectiveness of any policing strategy (i.e., [[Neighborhood Watch|neighborhood watch]], [[gun control]], foot patrols, etc.) is to assess total financial costs against [[clearance rates]] or [[arrest rates]]. Since terrorism is such a rare event phenomena, measuring arrests would be a naive way to test policy effectiveness.
Another methodological problem in the development of sociology of terrorism as a sub-field is one of finding operational measures for key concepts in the study of homeland security.<ref>Weinberg et al 1994</ref> Both terrorism and homeland security are relatively new concepts for social scientists, and academicians have yet to agree on the matter of how to properly conceptualize these ideas.
==Three sociological perspectives==
===Structural functionalism=== {{Main|Structural functionalism}} Functionalism is “the theory that various social institutions and processes in society exists to serve some important (or necessary) function to keep society running.” This sociological perspective draws on the work of sociologists like [[Émile Durkheim]], and gets its name from the idea that the best way to study society is to identify the [[Role|roles]] that different aspects of society play.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=29|edition=3}}</ref> [[Deviance (sociology)|Social deviance]], loosely understood, can be taken to mean any "transgression of socially established [[Social norm|norms]]." This can range from the minor–slamming a door in someone's face–to the major–a terrorist act. Thus terrorism is a deviant behavior.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=189|edition=3}}</ref> Functionalism sees terrorism–which is a form of [[crime]]–as a temporary deviation from the normal goings on of society, and is in a way functional to society.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref>
A sociologist that utilizes structural functionalism would explain the existence of any social phenomena by the function they perform. Therefore, terrorism is functional because it joins individuals together in opposition, and brings a sense of belonging to the group opposing it. This feeling of [[group solidarity]] would help prevent [[Anomie|''anomie'']], which is the stage where people do not need to follow any norms of society in order to survive in society.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref>
Terrorists, like other criminals, become what is known as a reference point; individuals use a reference point as a standard for evaluation. The norms and rules of society become clearer, and are seen as necessary, in comparison to terrorism. In order to protect the [[Status quo|''status quo'']], society uses terrorism as a way to reassert the importance of social norms in the lives of individuals. Thus individuals see terrorism as a threat to the [[social equilibrium]] and their life in a functioning society.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref> Functionalists believe that social change is required to keep a healthy society. Slow, well-planned, and evolutionary method-types change a healthy society socially. These social changes often come about from a drastic need for change and are preceded by a social shock. Terrorism brings about a social shock that moves society towards a change in direction that enables it to find new ways in which to protect itself. Functionalists view these new changes as providing society with a healthy and slow-paced [[social change]] that was needed. Terrorism thus becomes an expected and needed shock, and therefore can be seen in a sense to encourage society to change for the better.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref>
===Conflict theory=== {{Main|Conflict theories}} Conflict theory is “the idea that conflict between competing interests is the basic, animating force of social change and society in general." <ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=30|edition=3}}</ref> A conflict theorist generally sees that the control of conflict equals the ability of one group to suppress the group that they are opposing, and that [[Civil law (common law)|civil law]] is a technique of defining and maintaining a social order that benefits some at the expense of others.
Conflict theorists view terrorism as a reaction to [[injustice]], which is probably created in the minds of terrorists due to misguidance, illiteracy, or unrealistic goals, and that violent behaviors expressed by terrorist organizations are the result of individual frustration, aggression or showing a readiness to fight. [[Political conflict]] makes people look for ways to explain and solve the problems they are facing. If the conflict is deeply rooted, and the current ideology proves unable to deal with the problems, people begin to turn to other ideologies that can often carry a religious theme to them. This is not to say that all forms of terrorist acts are committed by people that are religious. In 83% of the [[Suicide attack|suicide attackers]] worldwide, between 1980 and 2003, only 43% were identifiably religious.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hartmann|first1=Douglas|last2=Uggen|first2=Christopher|title=The Contexts Reader|date=2012|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|location=New York, New York|edition=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Brym|first1=Robert|title=Six Lessons of Suicide Bombers|date=2007|pages=22–30}}</ref>
Terrorists use violence because they believe that if they did not use violence they would lose a power struggle, which lead many conflict theorists to view it as a weapon of the weak. In [[Iraq]], between March 2003 and February 2006, 443 suicide missions took place with 71% belonging to [[al-Qaeda]]. They justified their actions in religious terms; viewing the [[Shia Islam in Iraq|Shi'a control of Iraq]] as abandoning religious principles. Suicide attacks against the Iraqi regime and its American and British supporters were seen as the means in which to accomplish this. Yet it was only under certain political conditions that suicide bombings spiked. The first condition being that it was in relation with the [[Counter-insurgency|counterinsurgency]] of the American and British militaries. The second being a strategic response to the [[Shia Islam|Shi'a]] control becoming more stabilized in Iraq.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hartmann|first1=Douglas|last2=Uggen|first2=Christopher|title=The Contexts Reader|date=2012|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|location=New York, New York|edition=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Brym|first1=Robert|title=Six Lessons of Suicide Bombers|date=2007|pages=22–30}}</ref> Terrorists do not have the money or the political power that is needed to wage war, so they use terrorism as a means, not a goal, to agitate the government in order to achieve their political objectives. Before committing an act of terror, a terrorist does not always weigh the cost and benefits of their actions, but rather is reacting from the humiliation and frustration they feel they are being subjected too.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hartmann|first1=Douglas|last2=Uggen|first2=Christopher|title=The Contexts Reader|date=2012|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|location=New York, New York|edition=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Brym|first1=Robert|title=Six Lessons of Suicide Bombers|date=2007|pages=22–30}}</ref>
===Symbolic interactionism=== {{Main|Symbolic interactionism}} Symbolic interactionism is “a [[Microsociology|micro-level theory]] in which shared meanings, originations, and assumptions form the basic motivations behind peoples’ actions." <ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=31|edition=3}}</ref> In symbolic interactionism, [[face-to-face interaction]] creates the social world. Individuals act on perceived meanings that appear to be self-constituting.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=32|edition=3}}</ref> Group membership is one of the major determinations if individual interpretations of reality, which enables symbolic interactionism to explain crime, and thus terrorism.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref>
Deviance, which terrorism falls under, can be explained by [[labeling theory]]. Labeling theory is “the belief that individuals subconsciously notice how others see or label them, and their reactions to those labels, over time, form the basis of their [[Self-concept|self-identity]]." <ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=206|edition=3}}</ref> [[Social groups]] create rules about what is acceptable behavior for people in society. When a rule is broken, society determines if the act was deviant. A person can only become deviant after a social reaction to an act committed is labeled deviant, and that original act is referred to as the [[primary deviance]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=209|edition=3}}</ref> Being labeled deviant causes a person to see themselves as deviants, which leads to said person performing more deviant acts, with each act being referred to as [[secondary deviance]]. Secondary deviance can quickly turn into a [[Social stigma|stigma]], which is a label that changes the way people see someone, and how individuals view themselves<ref>{{cite book|last1=Conley|first1=Dalton|title=You May Ask Yourself: An Introduction to Thinking Like a Sociologist|date=2013|publisher=W.W. Norton & Company|page=2011|edition=3}}</ref> According to symbolic interactionism, terrorism is treated as learned behaviors. Each person learns how to commit terrorism through interactions with terrorists. Involvement in the group is important in the learning process, and members, upon joining, are resocialized to the group’s version of [[Social reality|reality]]. The best way to accomplish this is to involve new members in terrorist acts, which leads the terrorist organization to become the only reference point for its members.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cinoglu|first1=H.|last2=Ozeren|first2=S|title=Classical Schools of Sociology and Terrorism|url=http://sbd.ogu.edu.tr/makaleler/1488711_2_Makale_3.pdf}}</ref>
Social learning theory plays a part in the [[socialization]] of terroristic behaviors. Learning theory states that a person becomes deviant because of an abundance of definitions that favor deviant behavior versus definitions that are unfavorable to such behaviors. This theory is broken down into four learning mechanisms: differential association, definitions, differential reinforcement, and imitation.
The first learning mechanism is [[differential association]], which refers to "direct association and interaction with others who engage in certain kinds of behaviors or express norms, values, and attitudes supportive of such behavior, as well as indirect association and identification with more distant reference groups." The groups that an individual are differentially associated with provides the context in which the social learning is operated. The greater the priority, intensity, duration, and frequency of the differential association the greater the effect on behavior. Hence, the theory in relation to terrorism is that the stronger someone's connection is towards a terrorist organization the better chance that person has of also exhibiting terroristic behaviors.
The second learning mechanism is definitions. Definitions refer to an "individual's own value and belief system about what is and is not acceptable behavior." These values are learned and reinforced through differential association. There are two types of definitions, general definition and specific definition. General definitions include broad beliefs about conformity that are influenced through conventional means and are often influenced by religious or moral values. Specific definitions are seen as those that align an individual with particular acts of crime. The greater the number of definitions the more likely a person will engage in criminal behavior. So the more definitions an individual has that favor terroristic behavior the greater chance that person has of committing a terroristic acts.
The third learning mechanism is [[differential reinforcement]]. Differential reinforcement "refers to the balance of anticipated or actual rewards and punishments that follow behavior." An individual refraining from committing a crime depends on a balance of past, present, and anticipated future rewards or punishments for their actions. In regards to terrorism, the more direct or indirect social interaction a person has towards terrorism the more likely they are to commit a terroristic act.
The fourth and final learning mechanism is [[imitation]]. "Imitation is the notion that individuals engage in behaviors that they have previously witnessed others doing." The characters being observed, the behaviors that are being witnessed, and the consequences for those behaviors determine how much an individual imitates a behavior. All of these things need to fall into place in order for an individual to imitate a terrorist.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Pauwels|first1=Lieven|last2=Schils|first2=Nele|title=Differential Online Exposure to Extremist Content and Political Violence: Testing the Relative Strength of Social Learning and Competing Perspectives|journal=Terrorism and Political Violence|volume=28|pages=1|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09546553.2013.876414|doi=10.1080/09546553.2013.876414|year=2014}}</ref>

{{infobox ethnic group | group = South African Australians | image = | population = 145,683 (by ancestry, [[Census in Australia#2011|2011 Census]])
108,955 (by birth, [[Census in Australia#2011|2011 Census]]) | popplace = {{Flatlist| * [[Perth]] * [[Melbourne]] * [[Sydney]] * [[Brisbane]] * [[Adelaide]] }} | langs = {{Flatlist| * [[English language|English]] * [[Afrikaans]] * [[Languages of South Africa|other South African languages]] }} | rels = Predominately [[Christianity]], followed by [[Judaism]] | related = [[Zimbabwean Australians]], [[Kenyan British]], [[Afrikaner]]s, [[British diaspora in Africa]], [[Indian South Africans]], [[South African Americans]] }} '''South African Australians''' are citizens of [[Australia]] who are of [[South Africa]]n descent. According to the 2006 Australian census 104,128 Australians were born in [[South Africa]].{{cite web| url = http://www.censusdata.abs.gov.au/ABSNavigation/prenav/ViewData?action=404&documentproductno=0&documenttype=Details&order=1&tabname=Details&areacode=0&issue=2006&producttype=Census%20Tables&javascript=true&textversion=false&navmapdisplayed=true&breadcrumb=POLTD&&collection=Census&period=2006&productlabel=Country%20of%20Birth%20of%20Person%20(full%20classification%20list)%20by%20Sex&producttype=Census%20Tables&method=Place%20of%20Usual%20Residence&topic=Birthplace& |title = 20680-Country of Birth of Person (full classification list) by Sex - Australia|format = Microsoft Excel download |publisher = [[Australian Bureau of Statistics]] | work = {{CensusAU|2006}}| accessdate = 2008-06-03}} Total count of persons: 19,855,288. Also in the Census 79,513 residents claimed South African ancestry, either alone or with another ancestry.{{cite web| url = http://www.censusdata.abs.gov.au/ABSNavigation/prenav/ViewData?breadcrumb=POLTD&method=Place%20of%20Usual%20Residence&subaction=-1&issue=2006&producttype=Census%20Tables&documentproductno=0&textversion=false&documenttype=Details&collection=Census&javascript=true&topic=Ancestry&action=404&productlabel=Ancestry%20(full%20classification%20list)%20by%20Sex&order=1&period=2006&tabname=Details&areacode=0&navmapdisplayed=true& | title = 20680-Ancestry (full classification list) by Sex - Australia| format = Microsoft Excel download |publisher = [[Australian Bureau of Statistics]] | work = {{CensusAU|2006}}| accessdate = 2008-06-02}} Total responses: 25,451,383 for total count of persons: 19,855,288. Immigration from South Africa to Australia, particularly by professionals, accelerated in the 1990s. The large majority of South African immigrants to Australia have been of British descent; only a very small percentage, around 2-3% have been of Afrikaans origin. [[File:Australian Census 2011 demographic map - Inner Sydney by POA - BCP field 1198 South African Total Responses.svg|300px|right|thumb|People with South African ancestry as a percentage of the population in [[Sydney]] divided geographically by postal area, as of the 2011 census]] More than half of the South African Australians arrived following the election of [[Nelson Mandela]] in 1994.[http://www.smh.com.au/news/opinion/the-african-migrants-who-fear-a-lower-standard-of-living-inaustralia/2008/06/06/1212259114357.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap1 ''The African migrants who fear a lower standard of living'' Sydney Morning Herald] A behaviour stigmatised by [[white South African]]s who remained in their homeland as "Packing for Perth". "Packing for Perth" (and the initials "PFP") was also a humorous dig and reference to supporters of the "Progressive Federal Party" - a political party formed in 1977 that drew support mainly from liberal English-speaking white people, typically, the very people who ended up immigrating. [[File:ABS-3401.0-OverseasArrivalsDeparturesAustralia-PermanentMovementSettlers CountryBirthMajorGroupsSelectedSourceCountries-Original-NumberMovements-SouthAfrica-A83808785C.svg|thumb|300px|The number of permanent settlers arriving in Australia from South Africa since 1991 (monthly)]] In 2007-08 4,000 South Africans permanently settled in Australia, a number that is slightly lower than previous years.[http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/2f762f95845417aeca25706c00834efa/EF8DA58E2C7A1E47CA2573D200110282?opendocument Year Book 2008] Sydney has the largest number of South African-born residents (28,425), followed by Perth (18,828), Melbourne (17,318) and Brisbane (12,821). ==Notable people== * [[Joany Badenhorst]] (paralympic snowboarder) * [[Wendy Botha]] (pro surfer) * [[Robin Bell]] (athlete) * [[Scherri-Lee Biggs]] (Miss Universe Australia 2011) * [[Lauren Brant]] (former Hi-5 member) * [[John Maxwell Coetzee]] (writer, 2003 [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] laureate) * [[Bryce Courtenay]] (writer) * [[Collette Dinnigan]] (fashion designer) * [[Anton Enus]] (SBS newsreader) * [[Damian Cupido]] (Australian rules football player) * [[Dane Haylett-Petty]] (rugby union football player) * [[Dean Geyer]] (singer, and actor) * [[David Gonski]] (chair, Australian Stock Exchange) * [[Frances Hargreaves]] (actress) * [[Cariba Heine]] (actress) * [[Robert Holmes à Court]] (1937-1990) (businessman, Australia's richest person) * [[Jason Johannisen]] (Australian Rules football player) * [[Craig Johnston]] (soccer player) * [[Dena Kaplan]] (actress) * [[Gail Kelly]] (CEO, Westpac) * [[Marius Kloppers]] (CEO, BHP) * [[Marnus Labuschagne]] (Australian Test cricketer) * [[Jessica Marais]] (actress) * [[Kerr Neilson]] (fund manager) * [[Craig Reucassel]] (comedian) * [[Lovemore N'dou]] (boxer) * [[Clyde Rathbone]] (rugby player) * [[Selwyn (singer)|Selwyn]] (R&B singer) * [[Troye Sivan]] (actor and singer-songwriter) * [[Tammin Sursok]] (actress) * [[Daniel Vickerman]] (rugby player) * [[Margaret Wild]] (writer) * [[Nathaniel Willemse]] (singer) * [[Young Pluto]] (boxer) * [[Rhys Wynne]] (soccer player) * [[Tadiwanashe Ndabambi]] (soccer player) == See also == {{Portal|Australia|South Africa}} * [[South African diaspora]] * [[African Australians]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{South African diaspora}} {{African Australian}} {{Ethnic groups in Australia}} [[Category:Australian people of South African descent| ]] [[Category:African Australian]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Australia]] [[Category:South African Australian|*]]

revision.comment: Remove 1 stray access-date. ([[User:GreenC bot/Job 5|GreenC bot job #5]])
revision.text:
'''Things of Science''' was an educational program launched by the nonprofit news syndicate [[Society for Science & the Public|Science Service]] in November 1940. The program consisted of a series of kits available by [[subscription]] and sent by mail monthly.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/doc/510949846.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Apr%2022,%201967&author=By%20Cynthia%20Parsons%20Education%20editor%20of%20The%20Christian%20Science%20Monitor&pub=Christian%20Science%20Monitor&edition=&startpage=&desc=Discovery%20comes%20in%20a%20box|title=Discovery comes in a box|last=Parsons|first=Cynthia|date=April 22, 1967|work=Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> The program continued until 1989. {{asof|2018}}, there is no mention of the program or its archives on the website of the Society for Science & the Public, which succeeded the old Science Service organization.
Each month, thousands of subscribers received a small blue box about the size of a [[VHS|videocasette]] containing some material such as nylon thread or dinosaur bones.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/djreprints/doc/131610860.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Aug%2029,%201946&author=&pub=Wall%20Street%20Journal&edition=&startpage=&desc=Thing-of-the-Month%20Club%20Gets%20Industry%20Aid%20For%20Its%20Science%20Service|title=Thing-of-the-Month Club Gets Industry Aid For Its Science Service|last=Robitscher|first=Jonas|date=August 29, 1946|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> The box contained a yellow booklet explaining the topic for that month, along with the pieces and supplies needed to cover the topic. Some kits would teach about a specific topic, such as [[coal]], [[static electricity]], [[mechanical linkage]]s, [[nonwoven fabric]]s, [[electroplating]], or [[optical illusions]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vxVSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_XYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2361,370608&dq=things-of-science&hl=en|title=Experimental unit shows seeing not believing|date=August 21, 1959|work=St. Petersburg Times|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> Other kits would provide parts to build items such as a small [[spectrograph]], [[telescope]], or [[pinhole camera]]. In addition to the monthly subscription, some kits were available for individual purchase, such as a "soilless gardening" unit which provided seeds, plant food, and instructions in [[hydroponics]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vWFkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=U3wNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4160,2587703&dq=things-of-science&hl=en|title=New Kit Grows Plants Without Soil|date=May 11, 1961|work=Calgary Herald|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> Some kits contained basic materials for simple experiments in psychology.<ref name="Schlosberg">{{cite journal |last1=Schlosberg |first1=Harold |title=Things of Science. |journal=American Psychologist |date=1953 |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=124–125 |doi=10.1037/h0053882 }}</ref>
The modest annual subscription price ($5 in the 1960s) covered the cost of printing and postage. The instructions were written by Science Service staff, and the kit materials were donated by various companies.<ref name="Knetzger">{{cite web |last1=Knetzger |first1=Bob |title=Things of Science |url=https://makezine.com/2011/01/25/things-of-science/ |website=Make: DIY Projects and Ideas for Makers |accessdate=29 June 2018 |date=25 January 2011}}</ref>
The Things of Science Club was started by Watson Davis, editor-in-chief of Science Service, because editors served by the service often asked for samples of the things the syndicate wrote about. The initial focus of the program was newspaper editors, but it soon shifted to young people. By 1946 the Science Service estimated that half of its subscribers were school groups and science clubs, and the other half were individuals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ecg.mit.edu/george/tos/|title=Rediscovering Things of Science|last=Moody|first=George B.|work=Massachusetts Institute of Technology|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref> Membership in the club was limited to a few thousand because some of the "things", such as dinosaur bones, were hard to come by.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1hwiAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QKQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4985,4298460&dq=things-of-science&hl=en|title=Thing-of-the-Month Club will provide remarkable objects|last=Othman|first=Frederick C.|date=October 7, 1947|work=San Jose Evening News|accessdate=1 November 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://ecg.mit.edu/george/tos/ Rediscovering Things of Science] — includes a partial list of the kits *[http://underlandia.com/index.php/2017/09/02/things-of-science/ Things of Science] — scans of the instruction booklets for many of the kits *[https://makezine.com/2011/01/25/things-of-science/ Things of Science] — article in ''Make'' magazine
[[Category:Society for Science and the Public]] [[Category:Science education]]

page.title: Urban rail in the United Kingdom

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}} {{Use British English|date=August 2017}} [[File:Urban rail in the UK.svg|300px|right]] '''Urban rail''', '''[[commuter rail]]''', '''regional rail''', or '''suburban rail''' plays a key role in [[public transport]] in many of the [[United Kingdom]]'s major cities. Urban rail is defined as a rail service between a central business district and suburbs or other locations that draw large numbers of people on a daily basis. The trains providing such services may be termed commuter trains.<ref>http://www.123exp-trains.com/t/18664055193/,commuter%20rail,Regional%20rail</ref>
Unlike [[light rail]], urban rail is classed as [[heavy rail]], operating on lines shared with other passenger and [[freight]] trains with networks often larger than those of light rail.{{Citation needed|date=February 2009}} The infrastructure in [[Great Britain]] is owned by [[Network Rail]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.networkrail.co.uk/ |title=We own and operate Britain's rail infrastructure |publisher=Network Rail |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> and stations served by one urban rail network may be managed by different train companies. In [[Northern Ireland]] [[NI Railways]] have responsibility for both the infrastructure and operations.
==Advantages over light rail== [[File:Increase in passenger rail by sector 1994-2014.png|thumb|360px|Increase in passenger rail by sector 1994-2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dataportal.orr.gov.uk/displayreport/report/html/34856085-cf9c-4e0d-a7f8-8f9e5ee1b772 |title=Passenger kilometres by sector}}</ref> as well as a comparison with the [[London Underground]].<ref>https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/247943/response/615921/attach/3/150129HW%20LUDemandSince1956.xls</ref><ref>http://content.tfl.gov.uk/annual-report-2014-15.pdf</ref>]] As urban rail networks are part of the wider rail network, there is often easy interchange with [[Main line (railway)|mainline rail]], rail cards being accepted. [[bicycle|Cycles]] can be taken on board in the majority of cases, and existing railways can be used, rather than new light railways being built.
Unlike most light rail systems, only one ticket needs to be bought if a journey includes both mainline and urban rail. Urban rail usually has higher capacity than light rail because of longer trains (but often lower frequency), and higher average speed because of fewer stops.
In some cases, suburban railway networks have their own ticketing system, like in West Yorkshire.{{cn|date=May 2017}}
==Services== A few urban railways offer service during peak times only, and others operate less frequent trains during the evenings and on Sundays.
Networks often encompass a few major stations in a large city, with other stations being medium or minor. Services can be provided by one [[train operating company]] operating exclusively on an urban rail network, such as in [[Merseyside]], or by a company that also operates regional and national services, like in [[Bristol]], [[Cardiff]], [[Edinburgh]] and [[Glasgow]].
==Cities==
===Belfast=== [[File:Train, Dunmurry station - geograph.org.uk - 1558797.jpg|thumb|right|Belfast area [[NIR Class 3000|Class 3000]] commuter train at {{stnlnk|Dunmurry}}.]] In [[Northern Ireland]]'s capital, [[Northern Ireland Railways]] [[Belfast Suburban Rail]] serves [[Greater Belfast]]. Services run about every 20 minutes from 06:00 until 24:00 on: *[[Belfast-Larne railway line|Larne Line]]: [[Belfast Great Victoria Street railway station|Belfast Great Victoria Street]] - {{stnlnk|Belfast Central}} - {{stnlnk|Larne Harbour}} *[[Belfast-Newry railway line|Portadown Line]]: Belfast Central - Portadown - {{stnlnk|Newry}} *[[Belfast-Bangor railway line|Bangor Line]]: Belfast Great Victoria Street - Belfast Central - [[Sydenham railway station, Northern Ireland|Sydenham]] - Bangor
Some services run between Larne and Portadown, calling at all stations. Belfast Suburban Rail serves 39 different stations on three lines.
===Birmingham=== [[File:Birmingham & West Mids Passenger Railway Map.JPG|thumb|right|The West Midlands rail network]] [[File:Birmingham New Street railway station MMB 02 323204.jpg|thumb|right|[[British Rail Class 323|Class 323]] commuter train in the West Midlands]] Co-ordinated and subsidised by [[Transport for West Midlands]] (TfWM), (formerly known as Centro) [[West Midlands Trains]] operates a [[List of railway stations in the West Midlands|network of 70 stations]] in the [[West Midlands (county)|West Midlands county]] focused on [[Birmingham]]. West Midlands Trains operate the West Midlands commuter routes under the ''West Midlands Railway'' branding to distinguish them from their longer-distance routes. The main city-centre station is [[Birmingham New Street railway station|Birmingham New Street]], operated by [[Network Rail]], the other city-centre stations are [[Birmingham Snow Hill railway station|Birmingham Snow Hill]] and [[Birmingham Moor Street railway station|Birmingham Moor Street]]. The other main stations in the West Midlands are {{stnlink|Wolverhampton}} and {{stnlink|Coventry}}.
During 2014/15, there were nearly 51 million rail passenger journeys in the TfWM area.<ref name=2015WM>{{cite web|title=2015 West Midlands Travel Trends|url=http://www.wmita.org.uk/media/8790/west-midlands-travel-trends-2015.pdf|publisher=Centro|accessdate=5 July 2016}}</ref> Birmingham has the highest proportion of rail commuters in England outside London.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tacking rail growth in the city regions.|url=http://www.pteg.net/system/files/general-docs/Modern_Railways_supplement.pdf|publisher=Modern Railways|accessdate=2 March 2013}}</ref> In the past few decades the proportion of journeys into central Birmingham by rail has grown sharply: 29% of journeys into Birmingham city centre in the peak hours were made by rail in 2015,<ref name=2015WM/> compared to 17% in 2001, 12% in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|title=Birmingham City Council Evidence All-Party Parliamentary Group for High Speed Rail March 2012|url=http://www.appghsr.co.uk/upload/Birmingham%20City%20Council%20submission.pdf|publisher=All-Party Parliamentary Group for High Speed Rail|accessdate=20 Sep 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Business Plan 2006 - Route 17: West Midlands - Network Rail|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:1uljgmOp0wsJ:www.networkrail.co.uk/documents/3115_Route_2017_West_Midlands.pdf+&hl=en&gl=uk&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgw2bkcUFSoyKs8iDXFWpgQT2Qsx7rrcMTQfVSi20QpVdVgluI6_I0g-kCQfiUj_LrhBrV5i-Y-edhSH9AZGFNZ5spctY9novvcxadmUcM_Sw6MxLvLetgzW0YsGFF69R8hirl8&sig=AHIEtbRGf63SRsczF-BiJRKZrQ0t5G-fFQ|publisher=www.networkrail.co.uk|accessdate=12 March 2013}}</ref>
Most of the Birmingham and West Midlands County local commuter lines are centred on New Street station, including the [[Cross-City Line]], the [[Chase Line]] and the [[Rugby-Birmingham-Stafford Line|Coventry-Wolverhampton Line]]. Three commuter routes, known collectively as the [[Snow Hill Lines]] run through Snow Hill and Moor Street stations. Services run at ten-minute frequencies on the busiest routes, with most other routes operating at least a 15-20 or 30 minute frequency. Routes are below:
West Midlands Trains routes operating from {{rws|Birmingham New Street}}:
* '''[[Rugby-Birmingham-Stafford Line|Birmingham Loop]]''' - [[Wolverhampton railway station|Wolverhampton]] - Birmingham New Street - [[Birmingham International railway station|Birmingham International]] - [[Coventry railway station|Coventry]]. * '''[[Cross-City Line]]''' - [[Lichfield Trent Valley railway station|Lichfield Trent Valley]] – Birmingham New Street – [[Longbridge railway station|Longbridge]] – [[Redditch railway station|Redditch]]. * '''[[Chase Line]]''' - Birmingham New Street - [[Walsall railway station|Walsall]] - [[Rugeley Trent Valley railway station|Rugeley Trent Valley]]. * '''[[Birmingham to Worcester via Bromsgrove Line|Birmingham-Worcester-Hereford]]''' - Birmingham New Street - {{rws|Bromsgrove}} - {{rws|Worcester Foregate Street}} - {{rws|Great Malvern}} - {{rws|Hereford}} * '''[[Wolverhampton-Shrewsbury line|Birmingham-Shrewsbury]]''' - Birmingham New Street - Wolverhampton - {{rws|Telford Central}} - [[Wellington (Shropshire) railway station|Wellington]] - {{rws|Shrewsbury}}
Three lines, known collectively as the '''[[Snow Hill Lines]]''' operate from {{rws|Birmingham Snow Hill}} and {{rws|Birmingham Moor Street}} stations:
* '''[[Chiltern Main Line]]''' - Birmingham Snow Hill - Birmingham Moor Street - {{rws|Solihull}} – [[Dorridge railway station|Dorridge]] – [[Leamington Spa railway station|Leamington Spa]]. * '''[[North Warwickshire Line]]''' - Birmingham Snow Hill - Birmingham Moor Street - {{rws|Whitlocks End}} – [[Stratford upon Avon railway station|Stratford upon Avon]]. * '''[[Birmingham to Worcester via Kidderminster Line]]''' - Birmingham Snow Hill - {{rws|Smethwick Galton Bridge}} - {{rws|Stourbridge Junction}} - {{rws|Kidderminster}} - [[Worcester Foregate Street railway station|Worcester]].
Other routes operating from the TfWM area but not centred on Birmingham include:
* '''[[Coventry to Nuneaton Line]]''' - Coventry - {{rws|Coventry Arena}} - {{rws|Bedworth}} - {{rws|Nuneaton}} * '''[[Stourbridge Town branch line]]''' - {{rws|Stourbridge Junction}} - {{rws|Stourbridge Town}}
The [[West Midlands Combined Authority]] created in 2016, is pursuing plans to restore local passenger services to the [[Camp Hill Line]] in southern Birmingham, which is currently freight only, by constructing new chords into Birmingham Moor Street station.<ref name=Chamberlain/> Restoration of local passenger services to the freight only [[Walsall to Wolverhampton Line]], is also being pursued.<ref>{{cite web|title=Could Moseley to Birmingham trains return to end commuter hell?|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/news/midlands-news/could-moseley-birmingham-trains-return-11443290|publisher=Birmingham Mail|accessdate=20 July 2016|date=9 June 2016}}</ref><ref name=Chamberlain>{{cite web|title=£4Bn West Midlands transport boost unveiled by council leaders|url=http://www.thechamberlainfiles.com/4bn-west-midlands-transport-boost-unveiled-by-council-leaders/|publisher=The Chamberlain Files|accessdate=20 July 2016|date=15 June 2016}}</ref>
Centro was created in 1969 following the [[Transport Act 1968]]. The [[Transport Act 1985]] deregulated and privatised bus services across the UK. WMPTE co-ordinated the services of all local private bus operators and adopted the name of Centro shortly afterwards to distinguish itself from its previous role as an operator.<ref>[http://www.centro.org.uk/corporateinformation/home.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081216005911/http://www.centro.org.uk/corporateinformation/home.asp |date=16 December 2008 }}</ref> In 2016 Centro was abolished and replaced with Transport for West Midlands.
===Bristol=== {{main article|Rail transport in Bristol}} [[File:GB Class 143 dmu 143603.jpg|thumb|left|[[British Rail Class 143|Class 143]] commuter train in Bristol]] [[File:Bristol area rail map.svg|thumb|right|Urban rail network in and around Bristol]] There are 13 suburban and two main-line stations ([[Bristol Temple Meads railway station|Bristol Temple Meads]] and [[Bristol Parkway railway station|Bristol Parkway]]) in [[Bristol]], all operated by [[First Great Western]]. The only commuter line is the 13.5 mile long [[Severn Beach Line]] with 11 stations and 374,000 journeys in 2005/6. The operator estimates that 57% of travellers on the line commute, rather than for leisure.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstgreatwestern.co.uk/Documents/Custom/Severn%20Beach%20Line%20Development%20Plan.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - Severn Beach Line Development Plan.doc |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> Services run every half an hour to [[Avonmouth railway station|Avonmouth]] and continue every hour to [[Severn Beach railway station|Severn Beach]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.firstgreatwestern.co.uk/Documents/Custom/Dec%2008%20BOOK%20E%20WEB%20(timetable%20only)%20.pdf |title=Layout 1 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> If given approval, then a further two commuter lines from [[Bristol Temple Meads railway station|Bristol Temple Meads]] to [[Portishead, Somerset|Portishead]] and [[Henbury]] would open in 2019<ref>{{cite web|url=http://travelwest.info/projects/metrowest/metrowest-phase-1 |title=MetroWest: Phase 1}}</ref> and 2021<ref>{{cite web|url=http://travelwest.info/project/metrowest-phase-2 |title=MetroWest: Phase 2}}</ref> respectively. Services also run from Gloucester - Westbury and Cardiff Central - Taunton via Bristol.
Other suburban stations lie on main lines, [[South Wales Main Line]] (Bristol – Cardiff via Newport), [[Great Western Main Line]] (Bristol – London via Bath, Chippenham, Swindon and Reading) and [[Wessex Main Line]] (Bristol – Southampton via Bath and Salisbury).
Commuter services operate to and from nearby [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]].<ref>http://www.firstgreatwestern.co.uk/Content.aspx?id=3396</ref>
===Cardiff=== {{see also|Rail transport in Cardiff}} [[File:ATW-142002-CardiffCentral-01.jpg|thumb|left|[[Arriva Trains Wales]] {{brc|142}} Cardiff commuter train]] [[File:South-east Wales rail network map.svg|thumb|right|The network within Cardiff]] The [[Valley Lines]] network of eight lines ([[Butetown Branch Line|Cardiff Bay Line]], [[Cardiff City Line|City Line]], [[Coryton Line]], [[Maesteg Line]], [[Merthyr Line]], [[Rhondda Line]], [[Rhymney Line]] and [[Vale of Glamorgan Line]]) incorporates 20 stations in [[Cardiff]], the capital of [[Wales]], and 61 in surrounding towns and villages. Its hubs are [[Cardiff Queen Street railway station|Cardiff Queen Street]] and [[Cardiff Central railway station|Cardiff Central]]. Train frequencies are up to every five minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arrivatrainswales.co.uk/WorkArea/showcontent.aspx?id=5482 |title=showcontent |publisher=Arrivatrainswales.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> The [[Ebbw Valley Railway]] also draws commuters to the capital.
[[Transport for Wales Rail|Transport for Wales]] operates the stations and services. In February 2008, the Ebbw Valley Railway re-opened after 45 years with an hourly service to Cardiff Central.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/wales/southeast/sites/ebbwvale/pages/railway.shtml |title=South East Wales Ebbw Vale - Ebbw Valley Railway |publisher=BBC |date=2008-06-02 |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> Until the line's closure in 1962, passengers had had to change at [[Newport railway station|Newport]].
The Maesteg line is incorporated into the wider network: trains continue to [[Cheltenham Spa railway station|Cheltenham Spa]] from Cardiff Central. The Vale of Glamorgan Line serves [[Cardiff International Airport]].
However, the network neglects large residential areas in the south-west and east of Cardiff,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arrivatrainswales.co.uk/WorkArea/showcontent.aspx?id=4776 |title=showcontent |publisher=Arrivatrainswales.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525204307/http://www.arrivatrainswales.co.uk/WorkArea/showcontent.aspx?id=4776 |archive-date=25 May 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> although the [[South Wales Main Line]] runs through these areas without any stations. These areas include [[Caerau, Cardiff|Caerau]] in the south-west and [[Rumney, Cardiff|Rumney]] and [[St Mellons]] in the east.
Between 1995 and 2001, the network (except the Maesteg Line) was operated by ''[[Valley Lines (train operating company)|Valley Lines]]'', the trading name of the Cardiff Railway Company. It then became part of the [[Wales & Borders]] franchise before becoming part of the [[Arriva Trains Wales]] franchise in 2003, and subsequently the [[Transport for Wales Rail|Transport for Wales]] franchise in 2018.
===Edinburgh=== [[File:Edinburgh Waverley Railway Station 04.JPG|thumb|right|Edinburgh commuter train]] [[Abellio ScotRail]] operates four commuter lines (with 40 stations) in and around the [[Scotland|Scottish]] capital: the [[North Clyde Line]], the [[Borders Railway]], the [[Edinburgh to Dunblane Line]] and the [[Fife Circle Line]]. [[Edinburgh Waverley railway station|Edinburgh Waverley]] and [[Haymarket railway station|Haymarket]] are the city's two major stations with connections to mainline services.
A project to open a [[Edinburgh Airport railway station|rail link to Edinburgh Airport]] was cancelled in September 2007 by the Scottish Government in favour of construction of a station at nearby [[Gogar, Edinburgh|Gogar]], which will connect with the [[Edinburgh tram network]] to take passengers to the terminal.<ref name=edinAirport>{{cite news | title = It's £30m down the drain | publisher = The Scotsman | url = http://news.scotsman.com/topics.cfm?tid=607&id=1546642007 | accessdate = 2007-10-02 | location=Edinburgh | date=2007-09-27}}</ref> A proposal to re-open the [[Edinburgh Suburban and Southside Junction Railway|Edinburgh suburban railway line]] has been made by campaigning groups.<ref name="CRAG">{{Cite web |url=http://www.reopenthesouthsub.org.uk/ |title=Capital Rail Action Group website |access-date=7 February 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140516205531/http://www.reopenthesouthsub.org.uk/ |archive-date=16 May 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Exeter=== Despite being a relatively small city, [[Exeter]] is served by four commuter lines/services. Nine railway stations are within its boundaries (seven of them being suburban), which means the city is served exceptionally well by rail for a city of its size. The main hub of the network is [[Exeter St Davids railway station]] which has six platforms and three operators serving the station. The three platform [[Exeter Central railway station]] also serves as a hub for the network being located in the city centre. However, the only long distance service that stops at the station is the [[West of England main line]].
The [[Avocet Line]] runs from Exeter St Davids to [[Exmouth]], a medium-sized commuter town and seaside resort, via [[Topsham, Devon|Topsham]], [[Exton, Devon|Exton]] and [[Lympstone]].
The [[Riviera Line]] runs from Exeter St Davids to [[Paignton]] via [[Teignmouth]], [[Newton Abbot]] and [[Torquay]].
The [[Tarka Line]] is the only railway line that serves [[North Devon]] and runs from Exeter St Davids to [[Barnstaple]] via [[Crediton]].
During rush hour, [[South West Trains]] operate commuter services that terminate at [[Honiton]].
===Glasgow=== {{main article|Strathclyde Partnership for Transport#Strathclyde rail services}} [[File:380004 at Largs 2011.jpg|thumb|left|Glasgow commuter train]] Glasgow is Scotland's biggest city and has the UK's largest suburban rail network outside London. Much of the network is electrified, with some lines operated by diesel trains. Trains are operated by [[Abellio ScotRail]]; [[Transport Scotland]] oversees the management of routes, fares and timetables for all train services in Scotland - until 2005, train services around Glasgow were managed by [[Strathclyde Partnership for Transport|Strathclyde Passenger Transport]]. Because of this historic split there are differences between train services in Strathclyde and the rest of Scotland. There is no [[First class travel]] in Strathclyde, and morning peak time finishes at 09:00 (rather than 09:15) with no evening peak time.
[[Glasgow Central railway station|Glasgow Central]] and [[Glasgow Queen Street]] are the two mainline train stations, both in the city centre. Services to the south leave from Central, and to the north leave from Queen Street. Two lines run underground east to west through the city centre: the North Clyde line through Queen Street and the Argyle Line through Central, from underground platforms below the mainline stations. The North Clyde and Argyle lines meet at [[Partick railway station|Partick]], which is also served by the [[Glasgow Subway]]. There are Subway stations near Central (St Enoch) and Queen Street (Buchanan Street).
A bus services to [[Glasgow International Airport]] operates from [[Paisley Gilmour Street railway station|Paisley Gilmour Street station]]. [[Glasgow Prestwick Airport]] has its own railway station on the Ayrshire Coast line, and is the only airport in Scotland with its own station. A [[Glasgow Airport Rail Link|direct rail link]] from Glasgow Central to Glasgow International Airport was planned, but was cancelled in 2009.
===Liverpool=== [[File:Merseyrail Map.svg|thumb|left|Merseyrail map]] [[File:508141-LiverpoolLS-01.jpg|thumb|right|Commuter train in Merseyside]] The partially underground [[Merseyrail]] network consists of three lines, the [[Northern Line (Merseyrail)|Northern Line]], [[Wirral Line]] and [[City Line (Merseyrail)|City Line]], which interconnect in Liverpool's city centre. The Northern and Wirral Lines run in tunnels in the centres of Liverpool and Birkenhead. Liverpool is the nucleus of the network, which sees 100,000 people a day travel through 68 stations on the electrified lines.<ref>[http://www.merseyrail.org/about/?sGUID=2a45e2d07d59c0d621570a918cb62195 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090218110233/http://www.merseyrail.org/about/?sGUID=2a45e2d07d59c0d621570a918cb62195 |date=18 February 2009 }}</ref>There is 21 stations on the City Line that serves the Merseyside area. The origins of the network are old, dating back 1848 and the [[Liverpool, Crosby and Southport Railway]], one of the world's first commuter lines, and to the 1886 [[Mersey Railway]], which was the world's second oldest underground railway. An early commuter was [[Nathaniel Hawthorne]], United Stated consul to Liverpool, 1853-57.
The 75 mile long electric third rail Northern and Wirral Lines are 100% dedicated Merseyrail lines operating separately from the City Line. The City Line currently uses diesel trains operated by [[Northern (train operating company)|Northern]]. The local passenger transport executive, [[Merseytravel]], brands all commuter rail lines running through Merseyside as Merseyrail with stations inside Merseyside branded as Merseyrail stations. The City Line will be fully electrified by the end of 2014.
The Northern and Wirral lines operate under the [[train operating company]] called Merseyrail. Commuter trains run on both the electrified lines.<ref>[http://www.merseyrail.org/documents/NetworkMap.pdf ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090206124018/http://www.merseyrail.org/documents/NetworkMap.pdf |date=6 February 2009 }}</ref> The service operates at metro frequencies in central Liverpool and Birkenhead.
The City Line is operated by [[Northern (train operating company)|Northern]] running into Merseyside from outside the region, receiving funding from Merseytravel. The City Line consists of non-electrified lines heading east and one electrified running south. {{stnlnk|Liverpool Lime Street}} is the terminus of the City Line, with a connection to the Wirral Line at Lime Street underground station. There is also a connection with the Northern Line at {{stnlnk|Liverpool South Parkway}} in the south of Liverpool. The City Line is to be electrified to the Wigan and Manchester branches.<ref>[http://www.sthelensreporter.co.uk/st-helens-news/Electric-rail-link-plans-for.5919874.jp Electrification of the Liverpool - Wigan Line]</ref> {{clear left}}
The network includes the following lines: * '''[[City Line (Merseyrail)|City Line]]:''' {{stnlnk|Liverpool Lime Street}} – {{stnlnk|Huyton}} – {{stnlnk|Wigan North Western}}<br />or Liverpool Lime Street – {{stnlnk|Liverpool South Parkway}} – {{stnlnk|Manchester Oxford Road}}<br />or Liverpool Lime Street – {{stnlnk|St Helens Junction}} – {{stnlnk|Manchester Victoria}}<br />or Liverpool Lime Street – St Helens Junction – {{stnlnk|Manchester Piccadilly}} – {{stnlnk|Manchester Airport}}<br />or Liverpool Lime Street – Huyton – {{stnlnk|St Helens Central}} – {{stnlnk|Preston}} – [[Blackpool North railway station|Blackpool North]] * '''[[Wirral Line]]:''' Liverpool Lime Street – {{stnlnk|Liverpool Central}} – [[Birkenhead Hamilton Square railway station|Birkenhead]] – {{stnlnk|West Kirby}} or {{stnlnk|New Brighton}} or {{stnlnk|Ellesmere Port}} or {{stnlnk|Chester}} * '''[[Northern Line (Merseyrail)|Northern Line]]:''' {{stnlnk|Hunts Cross}} – Liverpool South Parkway – Liverpool Central – {{stnlnk|Kirkby}} or {{stnlnk|Ormskirk}}<br />or Hunts Cross – Liverpool South Parkway – Liverpool Central – [[Bootle New Strand railway station|Bootle]] – {{stnlnk|Southport}}
===Leeds=== [[File:West Yorkshire rail network.jpg|thumb|right|[[West Yorkshire]] network]] [[File:Northern-144023-01.jpg|thumb|right|Metro commuter train]] The [[West Yorkshire Metro]] oversees [[Northern (train operating company)|Northern]] commuter trains on 11 lines connecting urban centres such as Leeds, Bradford, Wakefield and Huddersfield and small [[commuter town]]s and villages in the [[Leeds city region]], branded as Metro.<ref>http://www.wymetro.com/NR/rdonlyres/6C36F2BD-0290-45A3-B281-B05D91BB4BE3/0/WestYorkshiresRailNetwork.jpg</ref>
The network incorporates the following lines, which often continue to longer distance destinations: * '''[[Airedale Line]]:''' [[Leeds]]/[[Bradford]] - [[Skipton]] - [[Lancaster, England|Lancaster]] - [[Morecambe]] or [[Settle, North Yorkshire|Settle]] - [[Carlisle railway station|Carlisle]] * '''[[Caldervale Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Bradford]] - [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]] - [[Manchester Victoria railway station|Manchester Victoria]] or [[Blackpool]] * '''[[Hallam Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Castleford railway station|Castleford]] - [[Wakefield Kirkgate railway station|Wakefield Kirkgate]] - [[Barnsley]] - [[Sheffield]] * '''[[Harrogate Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Harrogate]] - [[Knaresborough]] - [[York]] * '''[[Huddersfield Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] or [[Wakefield]] - [[Huddersfield]] - [[Manchester Piccadilly railway station|Manchester Piccadilly]] - [[Manchester Airport railway station|Manchester Airport]] or [[Liverpool Lime Street railway station|Liverpool]] * '''[[Leeds-Bradford Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Bradford|Bradford Forster Square or Interchange]] (not a separate line, but a composite timetable of all Leeds to Bradford services on the Airedale and Calderdale Lines.) * '''[[Penistone Line]]:''' [[Huddersfield]] - [[Barnsley]] - [[Sheffield]] * '''[[Pontefract Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] or [[Wakefield]] - [[Pontefract]] - [[Goole]] * '''[[Wakefield Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Wakefield]] - [[Doncaster]] - [[Sheffield]] * '''[[Wharfedale Line]]:''' [[Leeds]] or [[Bradford]] - [[Ilkley]] * '''[[York & Selby Lines]]:''' [[Leeds]] - [[Selby]] - [[York]] - [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] - [[Scarborough, North Yorkshire|Scarborough]] - [[Middlesbrough]] - [[Newcastle upon Tyne]]
===Manchester=== {{See also|Transport in Manchester}} [[File:Manchester Urban.jpg|thumb|right|Urban rail in TfGM area]] [[File:Class_323_-_Manchester_Piccadilly.jpg|thumb|left|A south Manchester commuter train at [[Manchester Piccadilly railway station|Manchester Piccadilly]].]] Commuting via rail by wealthy merchants living in North [[Cheshire]] and South [[Lancashire]] into the centre of Manchester was a fairly early phenomenon thanks to the opening of railways such as the [[Liverpool and Manchester Railway]], [[Sheffield, Ashton-under-Lyne and Manchester Railway]], [[Manchester, South Junction and Altrincham Railway]] & [[Manchester, Sheffield and Lincolnshire Railway]], in the 1830s & 1840s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract;jsessionid=490812601421239E5DE971329DEC78EB.tomcat1?fromPage=online&aid=64589 |title=Cambridge Journals Online - Abstract |publisher=Journals.cambridge.org |date=2001-01-23 |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> All had stations in what were then the outskirts of Manchester, from where citizens could take a train into the centre of the city. [[Sale, Greater Manchester|Sale]], [[Alderley Edge]] and [[Wilmslow]] are examples of early settlements that had railway stations in the early-mid-19th century and grew into sizable commuter towns.
Urban rail services to [[Manchester]] nowadays forms part of the [[Northern (train operating company)|Northern]] network.
Around 25 million journeys are made on the Greater Manchester local rail network, compared to 34 million [[Manchester Metrolink|Metrolink]] tram journeys. Buses make up a far bigger number than both however with 225 million journeys per year.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.tfgm.com/Corporate/Media_Centre/Pages/facts_figures.aspx |title=TfGM Facts & Figures |access-date=10 October 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150704034705/http://www.tfgm.com/Corporate/Media_Centre/Pages/facts_figures.aspx |archive-date=4 July 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name=statsrelease>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/527742/light-rail-tram-ending-march-2016.pdf|publisher= [[Department for Transport]]|date=7 June 2016 |accessdate=8 June 2016 |title=Light Rail and Tram Statistics: England 2015/16}}</ref>
The biggest point of entry to the city is [[Manchester Piccadilly railway station|Manchester Piccadilly]] which accommodates 13 lines <ref name="northernrail.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.northernrail.org/travel/timetables/296800 |title=Travel Tools - Timetables - Manchester Piccadilly |publisher=Northern Rail |date=2010-12-12 |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> on which services are provided up to around every 15 minutes.<ref>http://www.northernrail.org/pdfs/timetables/20081117/15.pdf</ref>
These include lines to/from [[Bolton railway station|Bolton]], [[New Mills Central railway station|New Mills Central]], [[Crewe railway station|Crewe]], [[Liverpool Lime Street railway station|Liverpool Lime Street]], [[Chester railway station|Chester]], [[Warrington Central railway station|Warrington Central]], [[Hadfield railway station|Hadfield]] / [[Glossop railway station|Glossop]], [[Huddersfield railway station|Huddersfield]] and [[Southport railway station|Southport]].<ref name="northernrail.org"/>
There are also 11 routes from [[Manchester Victoria railway station|Manchester Victoria]], all operated by Northern.
Routes are as follows:
* '''[[Buxton Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Stockport}} - {{rws|Hazel Grove}} - {{rws|Buxton}} * '''[[Calder Valley Line]]''': Manchester Victoria - {{rws|Rochdale}} - {{rws|Blackburn}} / {{rws|Leeds}} * '''[[Crewe to Manchester Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Stockport}} / {{rws|Manchester Airport}} - {{rws|Wilmslow}} - {{rws|Crewe}} * '''[[Glossop Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Guide Bridge}} - {{rws|Glossop}} - {{rws|Hadfield}} * '''[[Hope Valley Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Guide Bridge}} - {{rws|Romiley}} - {{rws|Rose Hill Marple}} / {{rws|Marple}} / {{rws|Stockport}} - {{rws|Hazel Grove}} - {{rws|Chinley}} - {{rws|Sheffield}} * '''[[Huddersfield Line]]''': Manchester Victoria - {{rws|Ashton-under-Lyne}} - {{rws|Stalybridge}} - {{rws|Huddersfield}} * '''[[Liverpool to Manchester Lines|Manchester-Liverpool Lines]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Warrington Central}} - {{rws|Liverpool South Parkway}} - {{rws|Liverpool Lime Street}} / Manchester Victoria - {{rws|Earlestown}} - Liverpool Lime Street * '''[[Manchester to Preston Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly & Victoria - {{rws|Salford Crescent}} - {{rws|Bolton}} - {{rws|Preston}} * '''[[Manchester to Southport Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly & Victoria - {{rws|Salford Crescent}} - {{rws|Wigan Wallgate}} - {{rws|Southport}} * '''[[Mid-Cheshire Line]]''': Manchester Piccadilly - {{rws|Stockport}} - {{rws|Altrincham}} - {{rws|Chester}} * '''[[Ribble Valley Line]]''': Manchester Victoria - {{rws|Bolton}} - {{rws|Darwen}} - {{rws|Blackburn}} - {{rws|Clitheroe}}
[[List of railway stations in Greater Manchester|91 stations]] are within the Greater Manchester ticketing zone. There are links to the [[Manchester Metrolink|Metrolink]] tram network at Manchester Piccadilly, Manchester Victoria, Manchester Deansgate, Altrincham, Navigation Road, Eccles (400m walk), Rochdale, Ashton-under-Lyne (from 2013), East Didsbury (200m walk) and Manchester Airport. Tickets bought for rail travel within Greater Manchester ticketing zone to the four city-centre stations (Deansgate, Oxford Road, Victoria and Piccadilly) are to "Manchester Central Zone", rendered on the ticket as "MANCHESTER CTLZ", and allow free tram travel within the Metrolink tram city fare zone (eight stops within the Piccadilly-Victoria-Deansgate station triangle).
[[Transport for Greater Manchester]] co-ordinates rail services within [[Greater Manchester]]. It was created in 1969 as the SELNEC PTE (South East Lancashire North East Cheshire) following the [[Transport Act 1968]], and was renamed GMPTE in 1974 before becoming TfGM in 2011.
===Greater London=== {{See also|Transport in London#Heavy rail}} [[File:London_Railway_Network.jpg|thumb|The London railway network]] Stations in London (apart from {{rws|Heathrow Central}}) are within Travelcard zones. Some stations outside Greater London, for example [[Chigwell tube station|Chigwell]] in [[Essex]], are within zones 4-6; many stations outside London are within zones 6-9, for example [[Amersham station|Amersham]] and {{rws|Shenfield}}, but some stations much closer to the Greater London boundary, like {{rws|Esher}} and {{rws|Staines}}, are not in any zone. London has an integrated ticketing system via the Travelcard or [[Oyster Card]] for buses, Docklands Light Railway, suburban rail, tram, Underground and Overground.
Unlike cities like Liverpool/Merseyside, Sydney and Paris, several operators provide suburban rail services. Most stations are served at least every 20 minutes, with many stations and routes having four, six or more trains per hour.
====c2c==== [[File:357014 at Upminster Bridge.JPG|thumb|right|c2c train bypassing Upminster Bridge]] [[c2c]] runs from [[Fenchurch street railway station|London Fenchurch Street]] through east London via [[Basildon railway station|Basildon]] (or [[Grays railway station|Grays]] and [[Tilbury Town railway station|Tilbury]]) to [[Southend Central railway station|Southend Central]] and [[Shoeburyness railway station|Shoeburyness]], serving eight stations in [[Greater London]]. {{clear right}}
====Chiltern Railways==== [[File:Chiltern at Marylebone.jpg|thumb|right|Chiltern Railways trains]] Chiltern Railways serves eight stations within London from [[Marylebone station|Marylebone]], with up to two trains per hour. {{rws|Sudbury & Harrow Road}}, London's least used station, has no services outside peak hours or on weekends.
There is a proposal for a Chiltern Metro Service between [[London Marylebone|Marylebone]] and [[West Ruislip railway station|West Ruislip]], operating at 4+ trains per hour, stopping at Wembley Stadium, Sudbury & Harrow Road, Sudbury Hill Harrow, Northolt Park, South Ruislip and West Ruislip. This would require a reversing facility at West Ruislip, passing loops at Sudbury Hill Harrow and Wembley Stadium (part of the old down fast line is in use as a central reversing siding for stock movements and eight-car shuttles for stadium events).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londontravelwatch.org.uk/get_document.php?id=497|title=There’s more to Chiltern than the Chilterns - The Case for a Chiltern Metro|date=January 2001|publisher=www.londontravelwatch.org.uk|access-date=1 February 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311030147/http://www.londontravelwatch.org.uk/get_document.php?id=497|archive-date=11 March 2007|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> {{clear right}}
====Thameslink and Great Northern==== [[File:Unit 319421 Farringdon.JPG|thumb|right|"Thameslink" service]] [[File:Class 700 at St Mary Cray.jpg|thumb|right|"Thameslink" Class 700 at St. Mary Cray]] The [[Thameslink and Great Northern]] network extends from [[Brighton railway station|Brighton]] to [[Bedford railway station|Bedford]] and from central London to [[Norfolk]]. Thameslink and Great Northern run two distinct services, [[Great Northern Route|Great Northern]] and [[Thameslink (route)|Thameslink]]. The Great Northern route runs from [[London King's Cross railway station|King's Cross]] and [[Moorgate station|Moorgate]]. Suburban services serve stations such as {{rws|Alexandra Palace}}, {{rws|Enfield Chase}} and {{rws|Oakleigh Park}}. Stations within London have three or six trains per hour, but stations on the [[Northern City Line|Northern City branch]] were not served on weekends until December 2015.
The Thameslink route is undergoing a [[Thameslink Programme|major upgrade due for completion in 2018]]. Trains run from {{rws|Bedford}} to {{rws|Brighton}} and from {{rws|Luton}} to [[Sutton railway station (London)|Sutton]]. The network links [[Luton Airport railway station|Luton Airport]], {{rws|St Pancras}} (for [[Eurostar]] services) and [[Gatwick Airport railway station|Gatwick Airport]] and [[Blackfriars station|London Blackfriars]], [[London Bridge station|London Bridge]] and [[Wimbledon station|Wimbledon]]. Stations in the north London and some south London suburbs are served every 15 minutes, while stations in central London are served every 15 minutes for each service. Stations on the [[Wimbledon Loop Line]] are served every 30 minutes.
====Greater Anglia==== [[File:Cheshunt railway station MMB 01 379026.jpg|thumb|right|Greater Anglia train at {{rws|Cheshunt}}]] [[Greater Anglia (train operating company)|Greater Anglia]] operates frequent services from {{rws|Southend Victoria}}, {{rws|Ipswich}}, {{rws|Clacton-on-Sea}} and {{rws|Braintree|England}} to [[Liverpool Street station]] throughout the day along the [[Great Eastern Main Line]], as well as from {{rws|Southminster}}, {{rws|Walton-on-the-Naze}} and {{rws|Harwich Town}} during the peak hours.
On the [[West Anglia Main Line|West Anglia]] and [[Lea Valley Lines|Lea Valley]] lines Greater Anglia run services from Liverpool Street to {{rws|Hertford East}} via Tottenham Hale and from [[Stratford station|Stratford]] via [[Tottenham Hale station|Tottenham Hale]] to {{rws|Bishops Stortford}}. The Stansted Express links London to [[London Stansted Airport|Stansted Airport]] and calls at Tottenham Hale. {{rws|Angel Road}} is a limited-service station. {{clear right}}
====Heathrow Connect and Great Western Railway==== [[File:360204 at Ealing Broadway.jpg|thumb|right|Heathrow Connect service at Ealing broadway]] [[Great Western Railway (train operating company)|Great Western Railway]] operates from [[Paddington station|Paddington]] to [[Greenford station|Greenford]], [[Slough]], [[Reading, Berkshire|Reading]] and [[Oxford]] stopping at west London suburbs including [[Ealing]], [[Southall]] and [[Hayes, Hillingdon|Hayes]]. It also operates [[Heathrow Connect]] jointly with [[Heathrow Airport Holdings]], with services from Paddington and calling at all stations between [[Ealing Broadway station|Ealing Broadway]] and [[Heathrow Terminal 4 railway station|Heathrow Terminal 4]]. Great Western Railway also operate services to [[South Wales]] and [[South West England|Western England]]. Stations within London are served by two or four trains per hour. {{clear right}}
====London Overground====
[[File:Gospel Oak railway station MMB 13 378216.jpg|thumb|right|A London Overground train leaves Gospel Oak]]
The [[London Overground]] (often shortened to ''Overground'') is operated by [[Arriva Rail London]] under a concession let by [[Transport for London]], which owns the [[London Underground]]. The Overground includes the [[Watford DC Line|Watford Local]], [[North London Line|North]] & [[West London Line|West London]], [[East London Line|East London]] & [[South London Line|South]] and the [[Gospel Oak to Barking Line|Gospel Oak to Barking]] lines. It is the only National Rail service shown on the London Underground map.<ref>http://www.tfl.gov.uk/assets/downloads/standard-tube-map.gif</ref> All stations are served at least every 20 minutes, with stations between {{rws|Dalston Junction}} and {{rws|Surrey Quays}} on the East London Line having 16 trains per hour in each direction.
On the [[West Anglia Main Line|West Anglia]] and [[Lea Valley Lines|Lea Valley]] lines, four trains per hour go to {{rws|Chingford}} and four via {{rws|Edmonton Green}}, with two continuing to {{rws|Enfield Town}} or {{rws|Cheshunt}}.
====Southeastern==== [[File:Class376londonbridge.jpg|thumb|right|Southeastern commuter train]] [[Southeastern (train operating company)|Southeastern]] operates over a large network in south-east London, with services reaching Kent and parts of East Sussex, covering {{convert|741|km|mi|abbr=on}} of railway. Its London termini are [[Charing Cross railway station|Charing Cross]], Victoria, Blackfriars, [[Cannon Street railway station|Cannon Street]], [[London Bridge railway station|London Bridge]] and St Pancras International. Southeastern provides most of its stations with a frequency of 4-6 trains per hour. Stations on the [[Bromley North Line]] are served every 20 minutes and stations on the [[Catford Loop Line]] every 30 minutes. {{clear right}}
====Southern==== [[File:Unit 377125 at Sutton (Surrey).JPG|thumb|right|Southern commuter train]] [[Southern (train operating company)|Southern]] provides services in [[south London]] and between [[central London]] and the South Coast, through East and [[West Sussex]] and [[Surrey]], and parts of [[Kent]] and [[Hampshire]].<ref>http://www.southernrailway.com/main.php?page_id=41</ref> Southern manages 167 stations and operates up to every 15 minutes on 14 lines south from [[London Victoria]] via {{rws|Clapham Junction}}, and 10 from [[London Bridge railway station|London Bridge]]. All but five Southern stations in the London Travelcard zones are served at least every 20 minutes. {{clear right}}
====South Western Railway==== [[File:Gb-emudc-455732-2.jpg|thumb|right|South West Trains service at Wimbledon]] [[South Western Railway (train operating company)|South Western Railway]] (formerly [[South West Trains]] (SWT)) operates out of [[London Waterloo|Waterloo]] via Clapham Junction, with 160 million passenger journeys on the wider network each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southwesttrains.co.uk/SWtrains/_Aboutus/Corporate+Information/ |title=About us |publisher=South West Trains |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref> The SWT network is the busiest in the UK, serving the busiest railway station in terms of passenger numbers (Waterloo) and in terms of trains per hour (Clapham Junction). All SWT stations apart from Fulwell, Hampton, Berrylands, Thames Ditton, Hampton Court, Strawberry Hill and those on the Chessington Branch are served by at least four trains per hour. The residential station of {{rws|Earlsfield}} is served by 16 trains per hour, while [[Vauxhall station|Vauxhall]] is served by 26 trains per hour.
SWT also operates longer distance services as far as [[Weymouth, Dorset|Weymouth]], [[Portsmouth]], [[Bristol]] and [[Exeter]].<ref>http://www.southwesttrains.co.uk/NR/rdonlyres/1CCE490E-82E1-4F22-A39C-EE8A1A8A5682/0/SWTNetworkMar08.pdf</ref> {{clear right}}
====Crossrail==== [[Crossrail]] is a project to connect the [[Great Western Main Line]] with the [[Great Eastern Main Line]], via tunnels through central London, with a branch to {{rws|Abbey Wood}}. It is the largest construction project in Europe. Crossrail will start a full service in 2018, taking over suburban services operated by [[Abellio Greater Anglia]] to Shenfield, Heathrow Connect to Heathrow Airport and First Great Western to Reading.
Once opened, [[Crossrail]] will be one of three partially underground suburban rail networks in the [[United Kingdom]] as the network cannot be classed as a Metro system like the [[London Underground]] or the [[Glasgow Subway]]. The [[Merseyrail]] and Glasgow commuter rail networks also have below ground stations.
[[Crossrail 2]] is a prospective line running north-east to south-west through London.
===Newcastle Upon Tyne=== As well as the [[Tyne & Wear Metro]], [[Wearside]] and [[Tyneside]] are linked by fast Northern Rail trains.<ref>http://www.nexus.org.uk/rail</ref> The whole network is made up of two lines, the [[Durham Coast Line]] and the [[Tyne Valley Line]] which link Newcastle with [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]], [[Hexham]], [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]] and [[Middlesbrough]] with 25 stations overall. These services are funded by Nexus and is one of four transport systems serving [[Tyne and Wear]], with the others being the Metro, the [[Shields Ferry]] and the large bus network which serves the county and surrounding communities.<ref>http://www.nexus.org.uk/bus</ref> Northern Rail also runs services that terminate at [[Chathill]].
===Plymouth=== Plymouth is served by the [[Tamar Valley Line]] which primarily runs through suburban areas in the west of the city. The line has nine stations and terminates at [[Gunnislake railway station]] in the neighbouring county of [[Cornwall]]. Five of the stations are within the boundaries of [[Plymouth]] while an extra two are within the [[West Devon]] district and another two are in [[Cornwall]]. The only railway station in [[Plymouth]] which is not served by this line is [[St Budeaux Ferry Road railway station]] which is on the Cornish main line in the northwestern suburb of [[St Budeaux]]. The line may be extended to the eastern suburb of Plympton and two sites have been earmarked for a station.<ref>http://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/new-plymouth-metro-could-include-new-station-in-plympton/story-30156846-detail/story.html</ref>
===Largest Commuter Rail Networks=== This is a list for the largest commuter rail networks in the [[United Kingdom]] outside [[London]]. London's commuter rail network has several operators and over 500 stations on many different lines.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Name of City !! Number of Lines !! Number of Stations |- | [[Glasgow]] || 13 || 178 |- | [[Manchester]] || 11 || 91 |- | [[Cardiff]] || 8 || 81 |- |[[Leeds]] |12 |78 |- | [[Birmingham]] || 9 || 70 |- | [[Liverpool]] || 3 || 89 |- | [[Edinburgh]] || 4 || 40 |- | [[Belfast]] || 3 || 39 |- | [[Exeter]] || 3 || 32 |- | [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] || 2 || 25 |- | [[Bristol]] || 1 || 11 |- | [[Plymouth]] || 1 || 9 |- |}
